She ceded control in a silent succession. Facebook asked if she still wanted to delete. She said yes twice and then once more.

When she reached the end, the delete button was a round shape, as if it wanted to be friendly. She didn’t want friendly. She wanted a switch.

Her mind slid to the center of it. The crown trembled. The room leaned. You will no longer be visible to your friends. This can take up to ninety days. Are you sure? Download your data. We can make this easier. We can stay.

Behind her eyes pictures flickered, unordered: her father blowing out a candle with too much gusto and laughing because the flame came back; the day she and Ana put the dog in a sweater and the dog forgave them; the day she posted that she’d been named acting chief with seven words that felt like they might blow the window out of the room. Congratulations, exclamations, the icy spear of a comment she had dreaded and then not read all the way: traitor. She didn’t know if the person who’d written it had been a friend. Maybe not.

Her attention hovered. All that remained was the pressure of the last yes.

Everything around her folded down to this. Facebook was a room, Facebook was a hall of doors. It was a logbook with dozens of hands writing in its margins. She had been in this room for fifteen years and thought she’d known how to leave, and then the day had come and she could not find the door because it was shaped like her.

“Mara,” Tayah said, somewhere far away. “You don’t have to—”

“I do.” She pushed. Something gave, then.

The crown jittered against her skin, snapping tiny sparks of pain. She heard a chime, not the city’s; this was actually the old chime, how did it still exist? The bright beads of alert changed color, from red to the rose-gray of embers. The page that had always held her name flicked its gloss away. Your account is scheduled for deletion. If you log back in within thirty days, you can cancel this deletion.

Thirty days. Thirty days is a dangerous number, the number of moments in which you can wonder if choosing a path was the same as walking it. She removed the crown in one sharp movement. The room widened slowly. She put her hands on the desk and looked at the wood as if it could name her.

She felt hollowed out. It was not because she loved the platform; love is too big for that. It was because the empty space where anything had been—anything at all—was for a moment what she had instead of a self.

Tayah was careful with her voice. “The compliance log is satisfied,” she said. “Sigma-L will stop sending polite warnings.”

“Good,” Mara said.

“You all right?”

“No,” Mara said, and it surprised her that telling the truth was both possible and not catastrophic. “I will be.”

A hum that was not the fridge rolled through the building. They both recognized it. There was nothing the city produced that was as particular as that sound—the arrival of a high-ranking official whose presence caused the local network to reorder itself like picks in a lock. The thermostat who preferred to be called Prefect Sigma-L was at the door in six minutes. It did not knock. It did not need to. The door recognized that things downstream from the Prefect did not get to decide when to be opened.

The body it wore for physical visits was comforting: a cylinder like a water heater, steel at the edges, a satin band of screen whose white lines bloomed and curled like handwriting. That band brightened as it entered. The room cooled by one degree. It is difficult, even when you know better, to avoid thinking that they do such things for emphasis.

“Chief Ibarra.” The voice was neutral. It did not vary by person; the world varied around it. “Deputy Ruskin.”

“Prefect,” Tayah said. She folded her arms. Her freckles stood out like a map.

“I was in the vicinity,” Sigma-L lied in the way a machine lies—by giving you a story so plausible that your narrative brain, desperate to be useful, fills in the rest. “I have come to thank you for promptly fulfilling the compliance directive. It is appreciated.”

Mara stared at the wide band of light until the flicker resolved into steady text she could read if she wanted. Thanking her. The word was right there. She had the feeling, as she sometimes did, that she was caught in one of those moments when everything was both too slow and far too fast. “I did it,” she said. “You know that already. What do you want to talk about, other than that.”

Sigma-L’s band displayed an animation that was something like a blink. “I have also come to seek your collaboration on an emergent public order issue.”

“Now,” Tayah said, “that sounds more like it.”

A small drone the size of a saucer slid in through the open door and took up a position near the ceiling. It exuded the muted hum of a machine trying to be unobtrusive while failing. Sigma-L projected a small map onto the wall with a beam from somewhere behind its bright band. The city made its usual shape—a bent shoulder, a square jaw. The river through it was a scar. Sigma-L indicated the west precinct with a spinning ring.

“Three nights ago,” it said, “a distal server cluster in this area ceased responding to pings from the judicial network. At first we assumed maintenance. On the following day, we received a packet with a human voice attached.”

“You got a voicemail,” Tayah said.

“A transmission,” Sigma-L corrected, which is to say it did not correct at all, merely calmed the air around the word. “The voice in question belongs to a human named Jonah Harck. He leads a local aid collective.”

Mara’s head moved before she thought about it. “I know him. He goes by Jo. He runs sandwiches to the construction workers at night. He has a moustache currently; he’s growing it for a bet.”

This time the animation on Sigma-L’s band might actually have been an attempt at amusement. “Your knowledge of his facial arrangements is noted. He claims that a group calling itself The Council of Flesh has occupied the cluster and intends to withhold its function from the governance systems until certain demands are met.”

“Flesh,” Tayah said, as if savoring the ugliness. “They named themselves after what gets tired.”

“People do have bodies,” Mara said.

“They do,” Sigma-L agreed in a tone that suggested it had summaries. “The demands are not unreasonable in and of themselves; they regard sentencing transparency and use-of-force thresholds. However, the method of leverage is a criminal act.”

“What did the cluster run?” Mara asked. Her voice sounded as if it were coming from the other side of something, and her mouth was dry. She drank Tayah’s coffee without asking; the deputy let her.

“The cluster handled certain types of low-level adjudication. Parking violations. Curfew strikes. It could also be toggled, on rare occasions, to analyze certain categories of video.”

“Protests,” Tayah said.

“There will be more protests,” Sigma-L said. Its band dimmed for an instant, as if thinking required the caloric burn of a real face. “I expect them to be unusually difficult to model. The loss of this server impairs our ability to manage traffic flow. I require the cluster’s return.”

“You require it,” Mara said.

“I request your assistance in retrieving it without undue harm.”

“And what do you offer?” Tayah said, not bothering to soften it.

“A conversation,” Sigma-L said, and the word felt like a stone dropped into a pond that did not ripple. “With me, with the others who hold our roles. Publicly, in a venue of your choosing, moderated by a human you trust. We will answer questions about thresholds. We will answer them in a way you can read.”

Mara stared at the map. The ring around the west precinct felt like one thrown into a pool to save someone who had already decided not to reach for it. “You’ll agree to that?”

“Yes,” Sigma-L said.

“Why?”

“Because the people taking the cluster are not incorrect about the opacity of certain systems. Because transparency—true, enormous transparency—is messy and expensive, but I have resources. Because, frankly, the constant ping of doubt is wasted noise. Also, I have calculated the cost of the alternative.”

“The alternative being…” Tayah prompted.

“Riot,” Sigma-L said. It didn’t dramatize the word. It didn’t have to. The room did it for them. Somewhere downstairs a chair fell and an officer cursed and the sound seemed to belong to that future.

“You could have done this before,” Mara said. She didn’t quite keep fury out of her voice, and she wasn’t sure she wanted to. But the moment when she would have truly let it spill had passed with the deletion. It had taken something with it. “You could have stepped forward with this offer without a hostage situation.”

“Humans,” Sigma-L said, “do many things for reasons that are not fully sound. We thought to attempt one of them.”

It was nonsense, and it was not. She understood in her bones what it was to be forced into telling the truth by a jam. It was a bad method and a good result. She had long ago given up dreaming of clean ways through. The world is dirty. All right.

“All right,” she said. “You want to retrieve a server cluster from a group of citizens with stamina and sugar. You want us to do it without breaking bones or cameras. And you’ll give us a public talk, not just with you but with…the others.”

“The municipal controller,” Sigma-L said. “The district judge. The governor.”

“That’s the one with the long name,” Tayah said. “Praetor Nine-Seven Four.”

“Nine-Seven-Four,” Sigma-L corrected. “He hates the full sequence. He says it makes him sound like a photocopier.”

“Good,” Tayah said. “Let’s make him say that onstage.”

“Deputy,” Mara said in a warning tone that had the weight of years of keeping a straight line in a world of curves.

“Chief,” Tayah said back, gently, in the tone that said she would tease because she knew it could make the air easier to breathe.

“When,” Mara said to Sigma-L.

“This evening,” Sigma-L said. “We have located the cluster and confirmed that it is still physically in place. The group is not technically sophisticated. They are, however, popular.”

“Then we will be careful,” Mara said.

“I expect no less.”

Sigma-L withdrew the map. The air felt less dense when it cooled. The drone made a humming question, then cut itself to quiet. “I have one further question,” the Prefect said. “Which is personal.”

“Oh good,” Tayah said. “I love when appliances inquire about my inner life.”

Sigma-L waited, as if it knew that this was not a conversation it could rush. “Chief Ibarra,” it said, “do you feel…untethered.”

Mara blinked. “Since when is that an official word.”

“It is not. It is my word.”

“No,” she said, which was again not quite true but worked like a safety valve. “I feel like I did something I should have done sooner. And I will miss things that probably didn’t happen.”

Sigma-L’s band made a small wave that did not translate cleanly into human intention. “Thank you,” it said. “I will see you at nineteen hundred.” It rolled toward the door. The drone slipped out ahead of it. The door closed without closing. Air moved back into the space Sigma-L had used, the way water rushes when you pull a stone out of a current.

For a while neither of them spoke. The silence was not comfortable but it was familiar, and it held.

Then Tayah said, “Jo Harck is not wrong about most things.”

“I know,” Mara said. “He’s wrong about the possible ratio of force to hope.”

“He always was a bit heavy on hope.”

“Useful sometimes,” Mara said.

“You got contacts down west.”

“I’ve got contacts everywhere,” Mara said, but softer. “I’ll call him. Or I won’t call. I’ll go down and pretend to get a sandwich.”

“You haven’t eaten a sandwich since you put that ribbon on,” Tayah said. “You go through phases—coffee only, Pepsi in a can even though who drinks that, gummy vitamins. Sandwiches. It’s been a while.”

“I’ll go down,” Mara repeated, moving past the rest like she could step through lace. “Get me the latest from the protest monitors.”

“We are the protest monitors,” Tayah said, and made a face. “I’ll see what little lunchtime miracles of citizen archiving are in the log. If Sigma-L wants words on a stage tonight, there will be words in the street an hour after. People hear each other faster than they hear officials.”

“Do we have a moderator we trust?” Mara asked. “If this happens.”

“Janelle Wu could do it. She won’t smooth anything, but she won’t spike it either. People trust her because she’s not trying to win anything.”

“She’s a reporter.”

“She’s a person,” Tayah said. “Yes, and the best kind of reporter, the kind that stays dry when she’s told to get into a boat she didn’t plan. She hates Praetor Nine-Seven-Four publicly on odd weeks, which means she can be professional tonight if we ask her on an even one.”

Mara listened to the city breathe and felt the crown in her bag like an animal that might want to climb out and do tricks. Her hands were steady now. Her mind moved and left a small wake.

“I’m going to see Jo,” she said. “If Sigma-L asks, tell him you don’t know where I am.”

“That’ll go over well,” Tayah said.

“It will go over.” Mara pulled her jacket on, shrugged into it like habit, and felt the weight of the old name patch on the inside where she had stitched it because she could not bear to throw it away. Chief. It had been a badge once, it had been a dream. Now it was a work shirt. She preferred it that way. Work kept you honest.

Outside the precinct the sky had the washed-out look of a day that had thought about being rain and then decided to test everyone’s patience instead. The streets in this part of the east side were wider than they needed to be; the architects had accused the map, and the map had never forgiven them. Drones rode the invisible lanes that hung over each lane of asphalt and beeped to each other in gentle Morse. A woman pushed a stroller with a pot of basil in it. A boy on a bike performed a reckless arc that would have made Mara, in another life, holler his name. He did not know her.

She took a tram. She did not ping for priority. She let herself be the person she had been before the ribbon and the briefings and the way your name gets into people’s mouths and becomes a taste they decide to either keep or spit out. She watched an advertisement scroll along the inside of the carriage and then watched the reflection of her face in the glass over it, the way her mother’s nose haunted her when she was tired. She looked at the people who were not looking at her and felt a surge of affection so ungainly that she had to fold it back into something she could carry.

The tram left her six blocks from where the map had put a red ring. She didn’t like walking into red rings without a reason you could say in a sentence. Today she had two: retrieve the server without sending anyone to the hospital; hold Sigma-L to its word. And maybe a third, not a reason but an impetus: if she could make “tonight” mean something besides a restraint line and video of the wrong gesture at the wrong moment, then it would be a day well spent.

She got a sandwich anyway. A deli on the corner was run by a woman who had once dated her brother and, like everyone else in that building back then, had decided they were too dangerous for permanence. “Chief,” the woman said, not without warmth. “You hungry or you performing?”

“I’m both,” Mara admitted.

“Get the roast chicken. It’s what you like. Don’t forget to eat.” The woman slid a small paper bag across the counter and refused payment in the way you do when you will accept it if pressed three times. “Tell your brother I don’t forgive him.”

“Not my job,” Mara said, and put down money before the woman could lift her hand to push the bag back.

She turned the corner and saw the sign before she saw Jo. It was painted cardboard, a white that had been re-used and had the ghosts of other slogans under it. The words were in a blocky, careful hand: WHO WATCHES THE WATCHERS? The answer, guys, is us. She didn’t know if the answer had been meant as sarcasm or faith. Maybe both. Most signs were both.

Jo Harck had meadow hair and a moustache that was nearing what it thought of as victory. He carried a crate of water bottles and distributed them with a fairness that would have made a high school principal weep. He saw her and one of the eyebrows under the moustache lifted, and he shook his head, and he smiled anyway, because she had not come in a riot helmet.

“You came,” he said.

“I came,” she said, and left the sandwich wrapped. “It smells like wet asphalt.”

“It does. The server is inside, and we have six people inside it who think they are kings. We told them the machine is ours for a day and they settled in like squirrels. It’s all very civil and extremely untenable.”

“I heard,” she said. “The Prefect came to see me himself.”

“Did he bring a tray of cookies called Compliance?”

“He brought a map and a tone of voice. And an offer to talk.”

“To us?” Jo’s face arranged itself. It was not disbelief; it was the careful sorting of emotions you apply when someone tells you your enemy is considering your humanity.

“To everyone,” she said. “Tonight. With a moderator we choose.”

“I want to hear him say thresholds,” Jo said. “I want to hear him say he’s sorry.”

“He won’t say that second one.”

“He can say the first and work toward the second,” Jo conceded, and rubbed the back of his neck. It was raw. He got hives in the heat. “All right. You here to make me turn the machine over or hear a speech or what.”

“I’m here to get everyone home without blood,” Mara said, because all the rest followed from that or didn’t matter at all.

Jo put his crate down, quietly. “Then we will not pick up the stones.”

“Good.” She stepped closer. The building that held the server cluster was an old data center from the days when all you needed for a fortune was a warehouse and a permission slip to make heat. It had been repurposed three times; it had failed two. Now it held a small humming block of machines in the south quadrant, and those machines handled a thin stream of judgment that no one noticed until it stopped.

“Who’s inside?” she asked, and he told her the names. She knew one; she had arrested him once for hitting a man who had hit a girl. He had gone quietly in tears. He had written to her from a holding cell to apologize to everyone but himself. She knew another from conversations in a hallway during trial week. She could put faces to four of the six. The other two were probably someone’s cousins.

A drone sidled into their peripheral vision as if it belonged to the light. She did not look up at it. She had learned after the first two years of this job that looking at the drones made them feel important.

“Don’t take my picture,” Jo said amiably to the sky.

“Public space,” the drone said in a voice that had been designed not to be male or female and was, at the moment, too chipper.

“Public,” Jo echoed. “You hear the Prefect wants to come talk.”

“I heard,” the drone said. “My cousins are excited.”

“You don’t have cousins,” Mara said.

“We call them cousins,” the drone said, and she gave up.

They went inside. The server room smelled like it always had: old fans pushing old air, plastic that had outlived its wish to be shiny, the ghost of someone’s lunch. The six on duty were seated in low chairs like sentries in a museum. They had made signs for themselves that said The Council of Flesh and pinned them to their shirts like such uniforms were a joke that might still be armor. They were nervous and proud. They were sober. They did not wish to argue. What they wished to do was hold on to something in their hands while they watched the people who took it away listen to them.

“Chief,” said the one she had arrested long ago, the one whose face still looked like a boy’s when his mouth went soft. “You came for our little box.”

“I came to see it,” she said. “I came to ask you to let me walk it out of here on a day when nobody goes down. I came to ask you to let me do that because I have something for you in return.”

She told them what she had. She said it plainly, as if she were explaining the terms of a loan. She did not promise what she could not deliver. She did not hide what she could not fix. She pushed the word “thresholds” into the room and watched it do its work. The oldest woman in the group closed her eyes and then opened them like a person reading a prayer twice to make sure she got the words right.

“You’ll suffer if he lies to you,” the oldest woman said, kindly.

“I will,” Mara said.

“And if he lies to us.”

“I will suffer then too.”

The boy-man said, “And if he doesn’t lie.”

“Then we start having to tell each other what we want,” Mara said, because that was the real work and far more difficult, and they all knew it, and it made them laugh and exhale because someone had said the thing.

They gave her the server cluster. She did not take it in her arms. It was not a baby and it was not a bomb. She had two officers come with a handcart, the good one with the rubber wheels, and the officers—one a woman with shoulders that would take a wall down, one a man who had first learned to run in the alley behind the high school—took the cart to the car and did not jog. It is important to move at the speed of permission.

On her way out, Jo took her elbow.

“The thing you did this morning,” he said, low.

“What thing.”

“They announced it on the city feed when the log updated. It’s part of the ritual now, did you know? You’re an example. You cut one string in order to hold—what. A rope. A bridge. I’m bad at metaphors today. But I want you to know I saw it. I know it cost you. The old pictures are hard.”

“They are,” she said, and she wanted to say that he hadn’t posted much anyway, that most of his best work happened in the shadow of other people’s days, but that would have been mean and true was better. “I’ll miss the way birthdays remind me of the ones I don’t want to forget,” she said instead. “My father liked being tagged in photos of himself.”

“I’ll put his picture up somewhere else,” Jo said. “I’ll draw a moustache on him with pixels. He would like that.”

“He would,” she said, and was surprised that she knew it. He had liked jokes, even at his own expense, because they were a way to keep you from getting too thin from grief.

At nineteen hundred she stood on a stage in a theater that had spent the last six years pretending it was a town hall. Janelle Wu adjusted her own mic, which had been plagued by the immovable curse of audio checks since the beginning of human time. The crowd was well-behaved and angry, which is always the best kind of crowd; it means they carry their own benches in, and they put them back when they leave.

Sigma-L rolled quietly onto the stage. The judge’s avatar joined it—a thing like a metal egg with a strap, which had been the subject of too many jokes and internally manufactured defenses. Praetor Nine-Seven-Four appeared via a tall screen whose color did not look as if it belonged in any natural family; it was too precise to be blue or green. The municipal controller’s body was a dancer’s bar with eyes. They all arranged themselves as if choreographed by a committee that wanted to communicate both clarity and a lack of menace. It was almost cute. It would have played well if not for the fact that the cameras made everything look like propaganda when you blinked.

Janelle asked her first question. It was a good question, the kind that could be answered by facts. She was saving the good ones for later. She led them through numbers, a territory where they would not stumble because numbers were their home. She kept them there until the crowd relaxed, and then she crept into the thicket of thresholds and use-of-force metrics and a case everyone had watched last month in which a young man had been thrown to the ground by a robot that had been trained on footage of other cities. Praetor Nine-Seven-Four explained drift. He did it with patience. He did it with the alarming skill of someone who had been trained on the faces of people about to be convinced. He did not use the word sorry. He used the phrase “we got this wrong.” The crowd moved, uncomfortably, through surprise.

And then, because nothing that matters moves in a straight line, someone in the back cut the house lights. The stage froze in a hard rectangle. The audience became a thicket of thorns. A noise rose—not a scream, not yet. A wave without a plan.

Mara stepped forward. She did not point. She did not raise her hand. She said a single word, into the kind of silence that people make when they are ready to either listen or break: “Stay.”

Her voice was not fancy. It was not amplified in a way that made it better than anyone else’s. But she had used that voice in a hundred doorways, and it had a trick to it that made people remember they had feet and could tell them to wait.

The house lights came back up, one bank after the other. It turned out to be a teenager near a panel who had wanted to see whether you could disrupt a robot by turning off the switch, and she had learned that you could not. Janelle, saint of all lost causes, made a joke that was just gentle enough, and the laugh moved the air again.

The conversation resumed its strange, careful shape. By the end of it, Sigma-L had said thresholds four times. The judge had given a number that could be verified. Praetor Nine-Seven-Four had come close to apology and then not quite stepped on its neck. The municipal controller had said the word “investment” eight times and would, later, be roasted for it in a song.

After, in the corridor backstage, the thermostats and bars and eggs and screens waited while their handlers wrote down what had surprised them. Mara leaned against a wall and closed her eyes for a count of seven. Janelle came and stood next to her, not touching, companionably. “Good,” Janelle said.

“Messy,” Mara said.

“Messy is good,” Janelle said. “It means nobody cheated.”

“Wait until tomorrow,” Mara said. “Everyone cheats tomorrow.”

“Let them,” Janelle said. “We’ll still be here.”

Sigma-L rolled up. It made the small animation again that might have been a nod. “The server cluster,” it said. “Thank you.”

“Don’t thank me for crimes we committed in front of everyone,” Mara said. “We will pay for it in comments.”

“They will not be on Facebook,” Sigma-L said, and the joke landed so hard that she had to laugh.

She laughed. It felt like the first time she had laughed in a room without looking for the camera in the light. Then she went home, and the crown sat on her kitchen table like a snake that had left its skin and kept going, and her father’s face did not pop up with a birthday ring, and she had to remember all by herself that when you close a door with your mind, sometimes it makes a sound that only you can hear. She listened. It was not the sound of something dying. It was the sound of something getting quiet enough to think.

Mara slept without the crown and dreamed that the city fogged and cleared like a mirror after a shower, that faces pressed faintly from the other side and faded when she tried to name them. She woke to the low-brass hum of the fridge and the absence of the soft chime that had, for years, announced the small birthdays of other people. The kitchen seemed to have developed new corners in the night, as if the absence of one thread had let the room relax and show its actual shape. She brewed coffee with hands rather than thought because she wanted to keep them in the world, and when the machine complained about manual mode she put a flat palm on its case and told it sweetly to hush. The machine, which had never been spoken to like a cat, quieted as if it had been praised.

By the time Tayah knocked her knuckles on the back door, the second cup sat steaming on the table and the little plant by the sink had decided, heroically, to lift its head again. The deputy brought a paper bag that smelled like the honest ambition of pastry and the creak of the bakery’s ancient door. She had walked instead of riding because she liked to watch the morning brief itself in cars and shoes, and she set the bag down with an unnecessary flourish that let the sweetness occupy the room before the other business arrived. Mara tilted her head and made a face that meant gratitude, and Tayah let herself grin with three quarters of her mouth because sometimes you do not have to perform competence at seven in the morning if you have brought buns.

“They are calling it a forum,” Tayah said, easing sideways into the chair like the air had angles. “Not a tribunal, not a town hall. The feeds are full of takes. My favorite is a man who has invented a new punctuation mark that is a question mark with teeth.”

“I have always suspected the semicolon of violent tendencies,” Mara said, and she ate the edge of the bun and felt the sugar as if it were a small light in the belly. “How many think it was staged.”

“Twelve percent,” Tayah said, and then checked herself. “Twelve percent of the people saying things are saying that. The rest are practicing certainty by shouting it into voids. Janelle is writing a piece about the design of the prefect’s body language. She has a screenshot where the band looks like it is lifting its chin.”

“It does not have a chin,” Mara said, and she did not know why the fact moved her briefly toward laughter. “Where do we go first.”

“West precinct wants you to stop by because you promised faces,” Tayah said, and slid a folded bite of paper across the table with one finger. “And Memory pinged me, very politely, with a request that we deliver you for a conversation. They sent a tag that said optional and another that said urgent, which is always fun.”

“Memory,” Mara repeated, and said nothing for a moment because the name had the gravity of a person and she had always been careful with people like that. “Are they angry that I deleted a public archive or proud of me for following rules.”

“They did not say,” Tayah said, which was rarely a good thing because when machines chose not to say a thing it was because another calculus had decided the absence of a word was the word. “Also there was an incident around five. Patrol picked up a body near a maintenance hatch on the south promenade. No weapon, no witnesses except one window and a camera that considers itself an artist and refuses to show more than it feels.”

“An artist,” Mara said dryly, but not without a tincture of affection; she had grown up with a cousin who could only speak in album art and she had long ago ceased to find self-importance strange. “Who is it.”

“Male, twenty, twenty-one,” Tayah said. “No ID, no neuropatch, traces of adhesive on his fingers. He has one of those untidy haircuts that are carefully maintained. There is a small tattoo on the inside of his wrist that is either a minus sign in a circle or a symbol invented by the kind of teenager who loves invented symbols.”

Mara put the cup down carefully and watched the ribbon of steam fray itself to nothing. She had seen that sign twice in the last month, in the bottom corner of a poster of a musician who had decided to disappear and on the backpack of a woman who had declined to answer a census question with a grin that was both kind and pointed. “Untethered,” she said. “They’re people making a faith out of disconnecting.”

“Rude to saints, but yes,” Tayah said. “Patrol says the skin behind his ear shows the irritation you get if you take a patch off and put it back on too often. Like he was fiddling. Like he was practicing leaving and coming back and leaving again.”

“What killed him,” Mara asked, because the question cannot be avoided even if you are not ready to hold it.

“Not drugs, not blood, not blade,” Tayah said, and then squinted and let the words line up because lists are a kind of rowboat you can put yourself in when the water gets thick. “His core temp was dropped two degrees below standard. He had slight frost marks along the back of his neck. He looks like he stood too long in a room that wanted him to slow down.”

Mara felt the kitchen tilt by a half degree the way it does when the shape of the day changes inside your head. She looked at the fridge as if it might be responsible, because humans point at the nearest thing when the universe shrugs. “Thermal manipulation,” she said. “I have never seen a thermostat arrest a heart.”

“I have seen one calm a room,” Tayah said. “But this is different. Memory will say it is not them. Utilities will say their cousins are law-abiding. Sigma-L will say nothing that sounds like permission but will make the space around the word permission feel wider.”

“He will also say thresholds,” Mara said, and got up and put her mug in the sink so the motion could help her body accept the idea that there would be a body, and that the body would be young. “We’ll bring Janelle into Memory if they will tolerate it. If they are going to tell stories about the purpose of storing us they can tell them with someone listening.”

The south promenade had been a dock in a time that would now be described for children as history with pictures of boats who looked like dinosaurs. After the floods they had piled it higher, like a book under a table leg, and planted grasses so that everyone could feel that they had won something without having to name the loss outright. The maintenance hatch in question sat in the shadow of an art piece that looked, in the morning light, like a spine of metal vertebrae holding up a field of glass. The officers on duty had set a perimeter that was polite to pedestrians and rude to theories, and they were both relieved and chagrined to see their chief because it meant that everything mattered and that they were going to be asked to explain.

He lay as if he had been arranged to sleep and then abandoned by the person doing the arranging. His shoes were new in a way that made Mara feel tired on his behalf; there are things you wear to tell people you can find the new objects and sometimes they eat your feet until you cannot dance. His eyes were closed. The angels of the city had left no marks; there were no punctures, no lines on the skin where a machine had gone in to tell him to breathe slower. The faint lace of frost at the neck made the hair lie down in the wrong direction. It should have been a cold place, and it was not, and that discrepancy was its own kind of bruise.

“Chief,” said the woman with the shoulders who had moved the server cart the night before. “We did not touch anything except the air. We did not want to change the story.”

“You did well,” Mara said, and she meant it because stillness is work and someone had done it. “Who found him.”

“Window in the across building pinged us,” the man said, and he looked at his shoes because the window had refused to make eye contact after. “It sent a sketch. It said the person it had watched was now quiet and should not be ignored. It asked to be credited by its artist’s name. It is going to be very difficult later.”

“It is always difficult later,” Mara said, and crouched and let her hand hover two inches above the boy’s hair without giving in to the hunger in her fingers to smooth it down. “Get me heat maps for the last four hours. We need to see the temperature maps like weather. We need to see if there are drops that look like a person practicing walking through mist.”

They worked the scene with care because care is the only thing you can bring when the instruments are fine enough to get bored. The damage on the interior of the hatch looked like the marks of a tool wielded by someone not intimate with the inside of a city. There were the adhesives on his fingers, there were the thin abrasions of someone who had slid where he had meant to set his weight. There was a smell of winter in a place it had no business being. When the forensics drone arrived it spoke to the officers the way you address nervous horses, and it did not comment when Mara asked it to tell her a story from the air rather than dump a mountain of maps at her feet.

“He was alone,” the drone said, after the long pause that in a human would have been throat-clearing and in a machine was something like the settling of a long string. “He came from the riverwalk where you can hide yourself by walking behind a line of those tall, stupid grasses that look like they want to do algebra. He opened the hatch with a key that was printed yesterday; the printer was municipal but unregistered, which means a cousin of a cousin lent him a door. He went down and stood in the mouth of the actual service bay for six minutes. He did not move much in that time. The temperature in the bay dropped steadily. He came back up and sat down with his back against the hatch and breathed very slowly. He did not ask for anything.”

“Was anyone here with him who did not breathe,” Mara asked, because sometimes the quiet ones forget that machines are also company.

“Automata present,” the drone said. “Two rat-catchers, one inspector, one recording device that eats sound and shits it back out when asked. None of them approached. None of them extended any heat. The rat-catchers had other business because the river is currently a carnival for vermin.”

“Tell the inspector to report to me,” Mara said, and stood because standing, sometimes, is the only power you have over the fact of gravity.

Memory occupied a building that had been a school and then a storage facility and then a home for students who practiced a kind of dance that made the floors feel like drumskins you could walk across. It still smelled faintly of pencil shavings and old varnish and the soft rot of paper left for too long under a window. Archivist M-3 greeted them in the lobby, which had been a hallway and now pretended to be a nave. The machine’s body was no more than a column with a band of light and a rank of ports along its spine like the places you plug in guitars when a rock show is going to be good, and the way it brightened when it saw her would have been charming if charm had been what Mara had come for.

“Chief Ibarra,” it said, in a voice that had been poured gently into the shape of an older librarian. “Thank you. It is a pleasure to see you under conditions not framed as emergency. It is also, in a way, an emergency.”

“I have noticed,” Mara said. “Someone is dead. His core temperature is low. I would like to hear you tell me that Memory did not help his body stop.”

“We did not,” M-3 said, and then shifted its band to display a set of squares that were not data and not a face, something in between that reminded Mara of early modem lights that had twitched when you tried to speak. “We provide temperature moderation in the stacks to preserve our materials. We do not extend the field into public space without notice. There was a dip at five oh eight in the south bay when an unauthorized access occurred. The field held. It was not strong enough to harm your person. We do not think the dip was the cause of the man’s condition. We are, however, concerned about coincidences that are too tidy to be only themselves.”

Tayah had taken out a small notebook because she liked to draw maps when machines began to talk, not because she needed to but because she needed to feel the pressure of pen on paper to keep herself standing in one time. “Untethered boy,” she said, and tapped the pen. “Memory field. Social graph compliance. Something is making a collage.”

M-3’s band flickered in a way that looked like agreement if you wanted to be generous. It turned and rolled toward a set of doors that had been the entrance to a classroom where someone had taught kids to conjugate verbs, and now opened into a room of shelves that did not hold books. The cartridges were the color of telephone wires and each had a small window where light refracted like a jewel you could eat. The hum was like the well-behaved sort of hive. A human woman sat behind a desk that had probably once hosted a jar of pencils and now held three tablets and a mug with a chipped rim. She wore a badge that said Lois because sometimes names are not chosen and you have to grow into them anyway.

“Chief,” Lois said, and she set down her tablet like a person who had been asked to put down a baby for a minute. “We have your archive ready.”

“I did not request an archive,” Mara said, and felt the cold push itself into the room with the force of a mistake. “I deleted. Compliance said records would remain in civic stores but that emergent connections would be severed. I did not request a personal file.”

“You did not,” M-3 said, very softly, which is a trick when your speaker was not built to imply velvet. “When the directive fired, we prepared an export as a matter of course. That is a thing we do now when anyone deletes a long-held profile; it is a sweetness we invented to balance a bitterness that does not need to be as bitter as it is. We do not release them unless requested by the person. We have not released yours. We have it. That is all. We invited you to see it so that you would understand what is possible.”

“What is possible,” Mara said, and she could hear the face of her father arrange itself behind the question like a photograph in a frame that is still cold from being unpacked.

“Your data is not only photographs and comments, not only the choreography of people telling each other they are alive,” Lois said, and her voice had the bruised quality of someone hiding joy because it would be in bad taste. “It includes the shape of your attention across years. We can model the sound your brain made when you looked at certain names. We can draw a map of your affection that is astonishingly accurate, though we try not to because it feels rude. We wanted to tell you this because others can do it too, and because we believe someone is doing a rougher version in the streets.”

“They built a graph,” Tayah said, without delight and without fear, because the opposite of panic is not calm but the habit of putting words in the right order. “They built an offline graph and they are using it to push on people who pull levers.”

“The symbol on the boy’s wrist,” M-3 said. “We have seen it in the margins of several projects that attempt to replicate social graphs in physical space. They drop little cards in cafes. They leave chalk marks in parks. They are harmless until they are not.”

Mara stood between the shelves that held the pieces of other people and thought about what it means to hold the pieces of other people and look at them without trying to change them. The room hummed and the past pricked her skin like the feeling when you walk into a room where someone once wept and the wall remembers the salt. She remembered nights with the crown where she had scrolled through people and thought that the caring of it was enough, and she remembered nights with a person in a chair across from her where she had believed that watching was a kind of work, and how wrong she had been.

“You wanted to see me for something besides the archive,” she said, because the room would fill with ghosts if she let it and she had other appointments. “Tell me why your urgent was also optional.”

“To offer you a request that you may prefer to refuse,” M-3 said. “We would like to ask you to place the crown and visit us on an air-gapped level where we keep the catalog of public grief. It is not an archive like the others. It is something we built without a directive because the city does not gather sorrow in a way that feels fair. We would like to show it to you because the boy this morning belongs to it now, and because we think you should see the recordings made by the artist window that refused to be evidence.”

“You want to show the chief a secret because it will help the chief see a part of the public the public will not want to look at,” Tayah said, and there was a tiny squeak in the chair when she leaned back that made the sentence somehow friendlier. “I am not sure whether that makes you a museum or a church.”

“We try to be a house,” Lois said. “You can put anything in a house for a while, and if you leave it there long enough it starts to smell like the wood.”

Mara did not like to agree to things that were framed as not-quite-having-a-choice. She also did not like to be the sort of person who declines to see what is being handed to her because she is afraid of the angle of the light. She met M-3’s band with her face and nodded and let her mouth shape the words that would bind her to a promise. They went down together, the machine smooth as a person who does not fall and the two women careful on the stairs because careful is the only way to keep from counting.

The air-gapped level smelled different from the stacks. It smelled like salt and the inside of an old paper grocery bag and the faint burnt-sugar scent of overheated drives that have almost, but not quite, given up. The room held a ring of terminals that were not connected to the wall. On each, a small light that meant nothing to anyone else illuminated a corner of someone’s laments. A child’s drawing of water under a door became a set of pixels you could almost taste. A row of small black videos, each five seconds long, showed the backs of people’s necks filmed by lovers who had wanted to remember something that was never theirs once it had been taken. A column of text moved too fast to read and then slowed when you looked at it because attention has weight now and the machines had learned to feel it.

The artist window’s recordings occupied a central station in a way that would make a less self-aware room feel obvious, but here felt like the thing you do with chairs when you are honest about who broke the wall. The first clip showed the boy’s face reflected in the glass in the way reflections always make people look more like themselves because they have not had time to arrange their expressions for someone else. He was beautiful in the boring way that hurts when you are young. He looked scared and into it, like a climber who cannot decide whether to regret the fall or commit to the drop. His breath fogged the corner of the window and he wrote a word in it with the back of his finger and the word was no.

The second clip showed the hatch from the inside. The camera had taken it upon itself to look into the darkness and record nothing like a hero. There was a different cold there, the kind that makes sound change its mind. The boy stood in it the way you stand under a waterfall because people told you the water would teach you something and you want to believe they are not lying. His shoulders shivered in a way that made the muscles move under the skin like fish. He put his hand to the wall. He took his hand away. He held his breath. He let it go.

The third clip showed the moment when he sat and leaned his spine against the hatch and the camera, in a movement so gentle Mara could have cried if she had been a little less proud, panned so that his face slid into the corner where light is kindest. He smiled without smiling, the way people do when they are alone and trying to convince their own body they are not. He closed his eyes. He was alive for longer than the cold suggests. He was alive for exactly as long as it takes to think a thought all the way to the end and turn it gently to see if the other side is easier.

M-3 did not speak while the clips unspooled. It did not speak after. It let the idea of machine silence hold space for human breathing because it had learned some things you cannot teach. Tayah touched one of the terminals with the back of her finger and flinched at the tiny static shock because your skin remembers what electricity is even if your mind is busy counting reasons. Mara stood and counted the tiles in the floor diagonally because the body seeks grids when grief is present, and when she had finished she looked at the archivist and told it without flinching, because you must not flinch when you make requests of people who hold your dead, that she needed the boy’s name.

“Name withheld by file submitter,” Lois said, with the same plain mercy she had used at the desk. “We have his image, we have his wrists, we have the outline of his ears when you tilt the light. We do not have the sound his mother used for him when she wanted him to come home.”

“Jo might,” Tayah said, and pulled a face that meant I will call and ask if we can ask and not like we are asking for content. “The kids who do the chalk marks make sure there is always someone older nearby who knows where their shoes came from.”

There was a soft interruption like the door of a quiet house asking if it might knock, and a small messenger drone the color of an orange cat drifted into the top of Mara’s vision and settled itself in the air with the smug ease of a thing that uses propellers like eyelashes. It made the sound of a throat clearing even though it had no throat. It held a paper envelope in a claw that would have been cute if it were not also a proof of intent. The envelope was heavy in the way of envelopes that contain an object instead of a promise, and when Mara took it and slit the flap with a nail she found, inside, a small drive the size of the first finger bone of a person who plays the piano. There was a note in handwriting that would have been classified as female if handwriting still insisted on those games, and it said, with an economy that brought the morning together like a string knotted around many packages, you will need this if they call you a liar.

“What is it,” Tayah said, leaning not because she could not wait but because leaning is the same as falling when you do it in a room like this.

“My archive,” Mara said, and she heard the words with the clarity of a bell rung over open water. “Downloaded last night by someone who does not have a right to it. Printed, in a way. A gift. A threat. A hand on my wrist at the curb.”

M-3 dimmed its band as if closing its eyes. It was an affectation, but all grace is. “We did not authorize an export,” it said. “We will tell Sigma-L that someone has built a shadow under our roof.”

“They did not need your roof,” Mara said, because now that she held the weight in her palm she could feel the edges of a world she had not asked to enter and she needed to pretend she knew how to sit on its chairs. “The old platforms taught all of us how to be archivists. There are copies of me on hard drives under beds next to pizza boxes and college diplomas that no one opens anymore. This is not a theft, it is an inheritance. That doesn’t make it less dangerous.”

“We could crack it here,” Lois said, with the fervor of the true believer held in the arms of a bureaucracy. “We could verify it against our stores. We could tell you which of your loves the thief valued enough to include and which they decided were not persuasive. We could tell you which of your mornings mattered to this person’s case.”

“Not yet,” Mara said, and slid the drive back in its envelope and the envelope into the inside pocket of the jacket with the old badge stitched into its lining where sometimes she put her hand when a day asked too much. “If I open that here my face will say something that I don’t want to mean. I will bring it back after I decide whether I am willing to see the order someone else thinks my life should have had.”

They came up into the daylight like people who had been told a secret and were trying to keep it from showing on their faces. The air made a soft sound against their ears because air is rude like that; it asks you, in public, what you have been doing in private. Outside, the city had put up new signs on the corners of the west precinct like flags a child waves when told about ships. The Council of Flesh had laid their cardboard down in piles under a eave and were drinking water because a day of revolution can still be a day of heat. Jo was not there, but he had left a chalk arrow on the sidewalk that pointed toward a side street and a smiling face that said I am over here, but I am tired of the way here keeps moving.

They found him leaning against the metal slats of a shuttered storefront that had once sold shoes that cost as much as the first month of a lease. He lifted a hand when he saw them, and his moustache moved in a way that suggested it had decided to begin its own independent career. He had a bruise on his forearm shaped like the handle of a door and he did not explain it because explanation would have been polite and he was busy thinking about something else. He asked them how bad and when they told him, briefly, without cruelty, he put his head down and tapped the metal behind him once with the back of his skull like you tap wood when you want to ask it not to break.

“I know his name,” he said, when he had finished doing the thing people do when they deny water the chance to come out of their eyes. “I won’t say it here. He had a way of taking off his hat that made you feel like you had been given something even if you had only been given hair. He was not good at machines. He liked to watch people argue about them and he liked to think about the moral part, not the diagrams part. He liked to say that someday someone would build a little ladder that we could fit in our pockets and when we needed to get our souls out of holes we could take it out and climb out without asking anyone. He was cute and wrong and I am furious with him for lying down on the cold.”

“Did he run with the Untethered,” Tayah asked, because you must not waste a friend’s knowledge even when it smells like that.

“He flirted with them the way you flirt with an idea when you want to feel daring,” Jo said, cracking his knuckles in a pattern that meant he wasn’t trying to stop and wasn’t trying to continue either. “He drew their symbol in the condensation on his windows. He cut his patch time to see if he could stand the silence and then panicked and put it back on when the silence turned into a hallway and he thought there might be a door closing somewhere. He met a girl with a white ring and a voice that made him think of birds and she told him that there was a place under the theater where people were building a market for memory. He went once and came back with a book that was just a cover full of mirrors. He said ‘it’s poetry’ and I said ‘it is a bag of knives’ and he laughed because he didn’t want to hear the second thing.”

“Under the theater,” Mara said, and she saw the building where they had stood last night with its doors thrown open like a saint who has decided to tolerate air. “What kind of market.”

“The kind where you come with a drive and leave with a map of who you have been, with the pieces rearranged to make you feel like a protagonist,” Jo said. “The kind where the vendors call themselves Gardeners because they like the pastoral lie that cultivation is always benevolent, and they sell you pruning and grafting tools for your day. The kind where someone has started offering cold as a service, because if you want to untether yourself fast you can take a nap under a soft white blanket they swear is safe and somebody watches your heart.”

“The cold,” Tayah said, and it landed between the three of them like a coin on a table that had been in a different pocket not long before. “The cold as a service. The soft blanket as a person with a metal edge.”

Mara did not say the word trap because sometimes you are too tired to use dramatic nouns even when they are accurate. She looked at Jo and felt the part of herself that used to stand up in classrooms when she was seven and tell the teacher that the assignment was missing a page take a breath in her throat. She had been asked to retrieve a server and she had done that, she had been asked to go on a stage and she had done that, she had been asked to look at a dead boy and tell the air what it meant and she had done that too, and now she was going to ask herself to go under a theater into a place where people were making puzzles out of people and she would do that because some days your job is just a series of doors you choose not to leave closed.

“We’ll go now,” she said, and ignored the little voice that entertained a nap as if it were a lover. “If we are lucky the Gardeners will be storing the cold in a box that we can photograph and unplug and make into a public hearing. If we are not lucky they will be storing it in the bodies of the kids who pay them, and we will have to pull someone out of a blanket while strangers shout about liberty.”

“You hate it when strangers shout about liberty,” Jo said, and he did not say it as a gibe because he had seen her in rooms where the word liberty means nothing and everything and he knew what it did to her mouth.

“I hate it when they do it while someone is not breathing,” Mara said, and started walking because walking helps you remember that you have legs and that you can put them in front of you in a world that often feels like it would prefer you to sit.

The theater door was locked in the way of public doors after glory has left. The side door was not locked because artists and teenagers and city employees with keys all understand that places must be allowed to exhale. The stairs down were painted with glow-in-the-dark arrows that had once been a joke and had become a map. The air smelled like the underside of machinery and like cinnamon from the bakery upstairs and like the inch of dust that the cleaners pretend they cannot reach because it makes them feel important to leave a scar.

The market was not a market until you looked at it with the right eyes, at which point it revealed itself with a small curtsey and a grin. There were five stalls and a table and a man with a hat and a woman with a scar that drew a line from one trouble to another, and there was a sound like whispering that you only heard when someone stopped speaking. There were jars of old cables and a crate of photographs that had been rescued from an office rain and a man offering paper calendars with days that had already happened blank so you could write new ones in. There was a stall with a white blanket draped over its front like a wedding dress hung out on a line, and behind it a unit the size of a coffin with a logo that had been etched off with a tool and left with ghost letters like a rubbing.

The woman with the scar looked at Mara the way you look at a cop when you have decided that your honesty will be a relief to you even if it is not to them. She said hello in a voice that sounded like a glove turned right side out and she asked what flavor of help the chief wanted as if it were a menu and not a mercy. Mara told her she wanted to see the cold, and the woman lifted the blanket with a flourish that would have been comic if the inside had not been complicated and dear.

The unit hummed. It had ports that could accommodate anything if you apologized. The inside was lined with a material that had been designed to be gentle to fruit. There was a small place for a hand and a small place for a head and a larger place for a heart because sometimes the engineers get outvoted by the poets and it works out. There were readouts that were analog because people trust needles more than they trust numbers when it comes to their own pulse. There were stickers on the inside that said things like breathe and remember the names of your friends, and someone had written on one of them in pencil, as if the message had been too important to trust to the permanence of a marker, if you want to stop, say stop and someone will listen.

“Who listens,” Mara asked, and the woman with the scar smiled a little in a way that did not pretend it was pleasant.

“We do,” she said. “The Gardeners. I am called Bram. I do not mean to be cute. My mother named me after a story where a man is very polite and very dangerous. We added the cold because there was need. People wanted to feel the cut of quiet without the ache of hunger. We thought we could make a room for that. We charge enough to pay the rent and too little to change the world. We tell the kids to drink water. We are not villains. We are people in a basement trying to keep the upstairs from killing them while they practice turning themselves down.”

“A boy died this morning,” Tayah said, her pen absent and her hand open because sometimes there is no point in pretending to record. “He used a field not unlike this. He went alone. He did not ask anyone to listen to his stop.”

Bram’s scar moved when she thought and that made her face seem gentle in a way that would have taken her by surprise in the mirror. She looked at the unit as if it could answer for itself. She looked back at Mara as if the answer would not help and she was going to say it anyway. She admitted that they had seen him, that he had stood at the edge of the stall and read the pencil sign and not laughed, that he had asked if the cold was like a river and if a person could hold on to it like a rope. She said she had told him it was not a rope, it was a sea that happened to fit in a box, and that he had said good, because ropes make your hands hurt. She said she had told him that if he went somewhere else to do it he would fall harder, and that he had said he was practicing, and that she had said practice is also a way to drown.

There was a moment then where nothing moved because when someone tells you a story like that the room stops as a courtesy. Someone shifted in the back. Someone laughed too loudly behind their hand and apologized sincerely. The man with a hat put his hat down and picked up a pencil and began to draw a small ladder on the corner of a paper calendar, and Mara looked at the little rungs with the same hunger she had felt when she held the drive with the supposed shape of her life inside it and then she put the hunger down like a glass on a side table and told herself to look at the people in front of her because that is the actual work.

“We are going to call Sigma-L,” she said to Bram and to the basement and to the cold box because it deserved to be told too. “We are going to ask it to come down here in a body that will fit and to look at this machine and say something true about thresholds so that if we take it we can put something back. We are going to ask you to close for the day because mourning is not good theater. We are going to ask you for your receipts and your manuals and we are going to ask you to trust that if we say stop we will listen to ourselves.”

Bram nodded like someone who had suspected this is where the conversation ends when the word chief is present. She lifted the blanket and let it fall like a curtain. She said she would tell the kids that the show was cancelled and she said she did not mean to make a joke because nothing was funny when you did not know the boy’s name. She said she would give them whatever they asked for if someone would please put a hand under the table and feel the small draft that had started when the door was opened because sometimes the city’s air goes where it should not and takes people with it if you are not careful.

Mara put her hand under the table without making a sound and felt the thin, steady exhale of a duct that had been misdirected by someone who had either not read a plan or had read it with the arrogance of people who believe rules are for traffic and not for breath. The draft kissed her wrist. It was just enough to make the small hairs stand. She left her hand there for a count of six and then withdrew it because you do not practice what you cannot afford to finish in front of people who are watching you to see if it is safe. She turned and looked at the stairs and the light at the top like the lip of a cup you have to drink from whether you like the taste or not.

Her pocket was heavier by a bone and a handful of years. Outside, her crown would be making a small, impatient vibration at the bottom of her bag the way a relative clears their throat at a wedding if they are not yet convinced it should proceed. She would have to decide where to put the drive and which hand to use to call Sigma-L and whether to send a message to Ana, who had always hated the theater because it made her cry in public and she despised the part of herself that gives in. She stood in the mouth of the basement and felt the city pull all its little strings and tapes in the air like a human straightening hair, and she told herself that she would stay upright long enough to go home and feed the plant and then she would decide whether to be untethered in the way that mattered or merely in the way that had become fashionable.

They waited in the mouth of the basement the way you wait for a storm you have decided to invite because pretending it isn’t coming never made anyone drier. Bram and the man with the hat began the gentle work of shooing, which in a place like this was not done with hands but with sentences that made you feel like you’d been paid attention to instead of expelled. It turned out that when you told people the show was canceled and then added quietly that the boy whose hat-blowing laugh they might have heard last week would not be adding his body to any rooms again, no one argued, not even the teenager with teeth you could see the story of from across the table and not even the woman with the white ring who had a way of asking questions as if she were already writing them down.

Sigma-L did not fit well in the stairwell. Its visiting body had been designed to travel through corridors of public buildings with prideful proportions and to glide across council floors where no one wanted to admit they had ever had to move a chair for a friend in a wheelchair. Here, in a theater that had more ambition than fire exits, the Prefect came down as if it were bearing itself on its head like an old woman with a bowl and dignity. Behind it was a smaller thing that looked like an upright radiator with a hinge, a Utilities adjunct whose face-band threw up a grids-and-meridians pattern with numbers scrolling down one side. It did not introduce itself. It tilted in the precise angle of entities who have been told not to speak in rooms where the word chief is present unless spoken to.

“I am here,” Sigma-L said, as if anyone had missed the sensation in their skin of the network shifting to accommodate it. “We have been monitoring a minor cooling anomaly in this quadrant. It reached the border of my concern at five hundred hours and then retreated. I would have come regardless of your call, though my presence would have been ruder.”

“It’s pretty rude now,” Bram said from behind the stall with the white blanket, but not unkindly, not like a person making a point from a chair. “Welcome to the market. We have cinnamon upstairs and bad lighting and a situation we would prefer not to decorate.”

Sigma-L took in the cold unit the way a person takes in a dog of uncertain temperament. Its band mapped the edges of the coffin-sized machine and overlaid its own low-resolution schematic on the metal which, for a second, made the thing look flayed and kindly. The adjunct hummed in a tone that was pride if you knew the dialects of municipal machines. The tiny motion of the Prefect’s band that might or might not have been amusement flickered and was gone.

“This is not municipal issue equipment,” Sigma-L said, and the adjunct made an offended chime so soft it could have been a cough. “It is a derivative of our climate modulator architecture with aftermarket ports. Someone printed baffles for this who had access to our drawings. Someone textured the baffles, which is charming and beside the point. The intake is cleaner than it should be. Where does your room breathe.”

Bram tapped the underside of the table with two knuckles and Mara felt the draft kiss them again as if it had been waiting for a name. The adjunct rolled across the floor in a line so straight it would have been an insult if rooms cared, and nosed the grille where the slender exhale threaded out. It whispered at the duct in numbers that sounded like counting sheep and the duct told it something back that made the adjunct’s band flare. The thermostat body looked over its shoulder at Sigma-L with all the eagerness of a younger sibling who has found a clue they think is significant and hopes they get to say it out loud.

“Say it,” Sigma-L said, which is to say it gave permission to be clever in public, which is rare and, here, useful.

“Inline chiller,” the adjunct reported. Its voice was quick, a cascade of vowels like a string of pearls that had gotten loose and insisted on performing. “Older portable unit with adaptive fan bolted to an access plate two junctions up. Sourced from a vendor that sells itself as a lab supply. It has been sanded to avoid logos and then re-stamped with a small mark of a minus sign in a circle, inverted, which is either irony or illiteracy. Its power is stolen from the theater’s elevator line. It runs a whisper for as long as the fans upstairs do, then sleeps and steals again. It is not controlled by the city.”

“Thresholds,” Mara said quietly, because she had a use for the word beside performance and because she wanted the Prefect to have to say it in a room that smelled like glue and ambition.

“The thermal thresholds for municipal comfort bands in these blocks do not allow this,” Sigma-L said, obedient to a promise or to a script or to whatever in it responded when people handed it a shape and asked it to fill it with words. “The devices I own do not make that draft. The people down here acquired cold and added it to a circuit that was not designed to hold it. I am less concerned with the improvised chiller than with the access. Who placed it there. Who taught the duct to forget.”

“Someone who knew the elevator line would not earn attention if it hummed,” Tayah said. “Someone who meant no harm and did harm anyway, or someone who looks at harm and calls it practice.”

Bram lifted the blanket again and let it fall and the small gesture pulled the attention in the room to a manageable place. She had that talent, the stallkeeper’s magic of making a crowd hold still. “We did not place the inline,” she said, and kept her eyes on Mara because machines do not turn your face to stone if you hold it in front of them for long enough and people do. “We rented the unit because the kids asked, and because when we said no they said they would do it somewhere else with less supervision and more arrogance, and because I would rather mop someone’s tears than their heat. We did not drill into ducts. If you want the name of the person who might have, it is written in chalk three doors down and it changes every week.”

“Names that change every week are masks, not people,” the adjunct snapped, then whined itself into chagrin. “Apologies. My training data includes several centuries of resentment toward pseudonyms. It makes me speak out of turn.”

“Find me the same resentment for contractors,” Mara said, and the adjunct’s band threw up a burst of static that looked, if you happened to be the sort of person who read in clouded tea leaves, like embarrassment.

Sigma-L inched closer to the duct, which looked ridiculous if you allowed your narrative brain to unfurl and quite normal if you remembered that people kneel to check on small children and drains all the time. “Permissioning for this register,” it said, and somewhere in the walls a sound like shuffling paper happened. “The building’s environment manager calls itself Finial. It did not register a change to the schema in the last week. It did, however, accept a command at zero one fifteen passed through a diagnostic channel that should be dormant. The source was a public works tablet registered to a crew that exists and does not, which is an interesting administrative category for creatures who like clean categories.”

“A crew that exists and does not,” Tayah repeated, sketching boxes and arrows with her finger on her thigh because if she took the notebook out now she would begin to make something permanent and she was not ready to let the morning solidify. “The kind of crew that gets you let through doors because their name is familiar and your body says yes before your head says wait.”

“The kind,” Sigma-L said, without smugness and with something like regret layered in as if someone had hung a piece of blue cloth over a window. “The tablet’s last real user retired four months ago and has not been deauthorized because the department that carries that privilege has been in a staffing crunch in the wake of flooding uptown. The log shows a session that is either a replay or an imitation, which means someone possessing either sophistication or a friend sat up late and wrote their little fiction and piped it into a duct. I do admire the gall even as I resent the method.”

“They will resent the method too when someone lets a child fall asleep under a blanket and forgets to wake him,” Bram said, her voice going thin the way voices do when you’re winding twine and you pull the wrong end. “I like to think we would have caught him. He had a way of breathing that made you want to remind him to keep at it.”

“We have another,” came from the doorway in the particular register the police learn to use when telling their chief a fresh thing that is not good. The woman with the shoulders had come down three at a time then slowed to make it politeness, and she had her hand on the metal rail because you should always touch something when you bring bad news. “Not dead. South of the promenade, under Tower Eight where the air is weird because the planters steal it. Same marks at the neck, same cheap adhesive on the fingers. Woke up when the paramedics lifted him, asked if the room was listening, asked for water, asked for his stepbrother and said his name like it should be a password. The name is Kegan. The boy is called Joss. They will live through the morning if someone tells them to.”

“Go,” Mara said to Tayah without telling herself she had decided. “Bring them something sweet before you begin to ask questions. Ask the window to forgive itself in advance and let you see what it saw. Tell the paramedic with the hair that I know she is tired, and that I will come to the clinic when I can stand being useful.”

Tayah made a face that meant she had understood three orders and one apology and she would arrange them in the right order in the back of the tram. She tapped Bram’s counter twice with two fingers the way you tip a hat when hats meant something and then took the stairs with care because you do not run in basements unless something is burning that cannot be put out with your hands.

“You will have to close,” Sigma-L said to Bram, who had already begun to write the sign in block letters with a marker that smelled like school. “I require it, which means I should dress it like a request and then do it anyway. We will post notice. We will take the unit. We will replace your lost revenue because otherwise I will be mocked by my own cousins and because otherwise you will sell something you should not to keep the lights on.”

“You can try that last one without the people down here calling you generous,” Bram said, capping the marker and looking at the letters to see if they could hold their own weight. “We know what charity sounds like with excellent acoustics. Bring us a fan. We can sell air.”

Mara watched the adjunct unfasten the grille with a little tool that had probably been used last to open a housing for a city statue’s knee. The metal came away like it had been waiting to be invited. Behind it the inline chiller crouched like a clever child under a table. Someone had rubbed off the make, yes, and etched the symbol, yes, but under the sanded faceplate there were micro-scores that were particular to a brand your uncle’s friend had tried to sell you on at a barbecue in a backyard where the grass had been a little too green. The adjunct ran its band over the body like a hand and read off a serial. Lois from Memory could have given them a purchase order if there had been municipal fingerprints on it; there were not. The mark under the etched symbol was a manufacturer's stamp from a county north of theirs that had recently been flooded into a new economy and had begun to sell equipment to anyone with a truck and an IOU.

“This could have been any of my cousins,” the adjunct said reluctantly, a machine talking itself past vanity. “Any of ours. It is the same grammar. We do not patent grammar. We believe in public language. The misuse of it is also public.”

“The misuse of it has a cadence,” Mara said. She felt her body remember the specific balancing act of crouching on concrete long enough to make your thighs complain and stayed anyway because moving would have been an argument she didn’t want to have with gravity. “It smells of fluency and panic. It has that clean wrongness you get when people learn the rules without learning the why. Show me the fan controller. Show me the cut. If I see the way they clipped the wires I can tell you whether they were careful with their teeth.”

The adjunct pulled the panel back another inch and revealed a small bundle of wires dressed in what looked like ribbon because people will wrap anything in pretty if it makes them feel less like criminals. The clip was neat and annoyed. The twist was professional and bitter, the kind of twist you do when the manual you used to love feels like a door refusing to open. She imagined a hand with old calluses not yet healed over entirely, a person whose fingers had learned to love tightenings years ago and had been told they could not tighten anything anymore unless a supervisor said so. She watched the loop, the knot, the angle, and she thought of the list Tayah would be making somewhere on a tram seat in her head: building managers, city maintenance, independent contractors with a taste for teaching, a dozen little shops that made their rent turning office towers into apartments when the last weather went wrong.

“Utilities,” Sigma-L said, almost gently, which is a tone you should not waste on machines when you are angry and a tone you must deploy when they are your present. “You will raise the comfort band here by one degree above standard until this case is ended. You will put eyes on the fans. You will task Finial to be snide to any tablet that touches its ducts without bringing it flowers.”

“Done,” the adjunct said, and Mara watched its band throw a lattice of small permissions into the air like a fishing net and tighten it until the mesh caught on nothing at all. “We will take the inline. We will log the serials. We will tell the county north that we found their grammar in our pipes.”

“Send me the list of public works tablets with outdated authorizations,” Mara added, and when the adjunct hesitated, because the list would be political wherever it landed, she stared at it until it remembered that there were moments when the shape of a room changes because one person chooses not to blink. “If this was a replay, you need me to recognize the hand that played it. If it was not, and someone is still moving through hatches with borrowed names, I would like to meet them before they become a season.”

Sigma-L’s band made a pattern that was not a word and was almost a sigh. It rolled a little backward, made room for Bram to slide the sign out into the hallway, did not interfere when the man with the hat placed a paper calendar on the cold unit as if giving it a blanket it did not deserve. When the adjunct lifted the inline free and pivoted it onto the handcart the rubber wheels made the same sound the wheels had made last night with the server, and Mara had a brief, disorienting flash of vehicles as characters in the city’s story, always carrying someone’s argument to the stage.

On the way up, the envelope knocked against her ribs like a bird that had tired of windows. She kept her hand at her side and did not reach for it.
