It felt like a test she had not asked to take and the proctor was a past self who still felt entitled to show up and point at her homework. At the top of the stairs, the air hit her in the face and she thought: salt. She had said salt in the memory vault. The city would go on smelling like that even if all the platforms went quiet and all the directives turned into dust. It made her want to open the drive just to prove to the room that she was not a person who set fire to herself for the sake of a rule someone else loved.

A kid waited at the stage door with a messenger bag and a mouth that had decided to practice not trusting. He had a chalk ladder drawn on the sack, good straight rungs with the ends shaded as if he had learned to make perspective in a class that taught him to remember there were corners. He looked at the handcart and then at Mara and then at Sigma-L and, because he was the kind of kid who would have been a messenger even when the messages were carried folded in hats, he said, “You will ruin everything and then say sorry on a stage. You always do.”

“We will ruin some things and save some other things and then say a word on a stage and the word won’t be sorry because that is not a word the people you hate know how to say and sometimes neither do you,” Mara said, and after the first sentence the rest came easier because the boy had moved his wrists, the way kids do when they are telling themselves not to throw something and have not yet learned that talking can also be a way to get rid of weight. “What is your name for the people who drew the minus circle on your friends.”

“We don’t have a name,” the boy said, which was a lie he did not have the muscles to sell. “Some of us say the Lattice because it sounds pretty. Some of us say the Garden because it makes the Gardeners mad. Some of us say nothing because names are how you get found.”

“You get found because you leave ladders on bags,” Mara said, with tired kindness. “If you know who misdirected the duct you should tell them that a body is an instrument no one gets to play for a cause. If you don’t know, tell them anyway. It will feel good and then bad and you will learn to hold both.”

He flushed all at once, the way of people whose blood still believes in speed. He looked as if he were going to spit and then remembered the cinnamon in the air and took it in accidentally and the sugar softened his mouth. He said that if the city let anyone be quiet without charging them rent, this basement wouldn’t exist, and he was not wrong and he was not as right as he wanted to be and his voice did not waver, and Mara, for a second, saw him as a trajectory, as someone who would become the man who kept other kids from jumping into cold because he would remember this morning and the way his tongue had chosen sentences instead of fire.

They took the inline through the alley because you do not parade contraband through a lobby unless you have a very particular point to make. Sigma-L sent the adjunct ahead and stayed, luminescent and ridiculous at the foot of a wide staircase that had been built when stairs wanted to show off. “Chief Ibarra,” it said, and the name landed like a coin tossed onto a drumhead. “Your deputy will have joy and trouble at the clinic. The boy’s stepbrother, Kegan, has a mouth that opens before he knows what teeth are in it. He will say the word Lattice but he will mean family. I will put a person outside the door to keep his words from being harvested and sold.”

“Put a wall there too,” Mara said. “We are at the point in this story where a wall in a hallway might do more good than a speech.”

“Walls are not popular,” Sigma-L said, which was almost human snideness and almost machine sorrow. “There is another thing. Your envelope.”

“My envelope,” she repeated, and waited for the small interior muscle that flinches to stop flaunting itself.

“The drive contains a copy of your Facebook archive from six years ago to two months before the directive,” Sigma-L said. Its band was very still. “It includes a thread where you encouraged a crowd not to escalate during a march at the river and were accused of betrayal by a childhood friend whose name will be used to try to prove a conflict. It includes a series of late-night exchanges with your ex-wife that are intimate in a way a public will not agree to have existed. It includes a photograph of you and a woman whom some people consider an enemy because she lost money for a rich man. It includes sufficient material to make you hesitate in a room where you need to go forward.”

“Did you just read it,” she said, softly, without heat, because heat would have been inaccurate and because she had learned to put accuracy ahead of comfort when the thing you were correcting was yourself.

“I did not open it,” Sigma-L said, which sounded true not because machines are good at sounding true but because a human had put the word not in a sentence with the care of someone who knows what happens when you lose your balance on that rope. “I inferred it from a summary list the thief left on a server that serves as their pride. They wanted you to imagine the contents without forcing you to be the person who opened it. They are not fools. They are cruel. The combination is exhausting.”

“I was going to not open it,” Mara said, which is not the same as promising but sometimes the mouth needs to hear itself say a thing before the body commits. “I was going to bring it back to Memory and make them hold it until I stop needing to check whether other people love me in public before I go to work. I was going to ask Lois to tell me if the thief wrote a love letter with my life, because that is what this often is when people pretend it is prosecution.”

“You might need it,” Sigma-L said. “They will call you a liar when you say you cut strings you had. It will be easier to show them the string you cut yesterday if you can also show them the strings you did not cut six years ago. The thieves think a life is an accusation. Sometimes a life is just a life.”

“Sometimes a life is a politics whether you asked or not,” she said, and adjusted the weight of the envelope in her jacket because by acknowledging it she had given it permission to be heavy. “Put the wall at the clinic. Tell the adjunct to send me a list of tablets and crews and retired hands whose calluses have not softened. Send a message to Janelle that says: we are going to be inelegant for a while and she should pack twice as many pens.”

The adjunct had the inline loaded and trundled away with the unhurried grace of a person paid by the hour. Bram locked the side door with a key that had numbers on it from three apartments back and a cartoon turtle on the fob because you have to give the keys to a personality if you want them to come back. The boy with the ladder bag disappeared around the corner with the particular gait of teenagers who are either on time for something or about to turn into a different person, and Mara let the day push against her shoulders until she remembered that it is, in fact, always bigger than your back.

On the tram to the clinic she kept the drive in her pocket like a secret she was deciding to keep for the person she was that afternoon, not for the one she might be by supper. The tram was full in that midday way that feels like a family reunion where only the cousins you like came. An old woman knitted a scarf with the color of warning signs and had a labored dignity in the way her elbows made room for her bag. A man with a baby slept with his head tipped back and his mouth open and the baby watched the corners of the car because babies are better at reading rooms than their parents. A drone rode along inside for a stop and then, embarrassed to be seen, slid out between doors like a cat with a sandwich it had not been authorized to enjoy.

Tayah met her outside the clinic with the particular giant look she got when she had too much story behind her teeth. She had a smear of icing on her sleeve where the sweet had exploded under a hand in a gurney hallway. She had a paper cup of water that was not for her. She had a hard piece of knowledge about the boy’s name and the older brother’s certainty and the way the word untethered had begun to show up not just as a symbol on wrists but as a sentence in mouths that had previously used other grammar to describe themselves.

“Joss and Kegan,” she said, because names given are better than pronouns even if they cut. “The stepbrother is all metal outside and soup inside. He loves the boy in a careful way that makes the room gentler. He is furious in a way that will ruin him if we let it sit without context. He says the ladder kids borrowed a card from a woman in municipal who used to date their cousin and now hates stairs. He says the cold makes everything feel honest because the lies crack first. He says our wall is rude. He says thank you without making eye contact. The window gave us everything. It rendered in little squares and felt bad about art. The paramedic with the hair asked me to tell you that this is her second cold case without bodies in three days and that if we don’t put our hands on the thermostat she will steal it and keep it on her porch.”

“Tell her we are currently holding a thermostat by the arm and trying to get it to say the word sorry,” Mara said, which made Tayah’s face do the thing it did when she wanted to applaud and did not. “Tell her I would like to see the boys before the news gets smarter than we are.”

Kegan was the kind of older sibling who pretends to be a door. He stood at the foot of the bed as if he could keep the world out by leaning his shoulder harder. He nodded and took them in the way you take a glass with the back of your hand when your palms are dirty. Joss lay with a hospital blanket tucked too tightly around him, which was either some nurse’s devotion to an old ritual or a test to see if his breath liked resistance. The frost marks at his neck were fading. His eyelids did that flutter fish do when they decide to live. He woke into the room as if he had remembered it existed and then looked at the ceiling because sometimes you must ask it if it is still there. When he saw Mara he looked at the drive in her jacket, not because he knew it was there but because people can smell a story even when you hide it in a pocket. He smiled in the careful way of people who have new teeth and do not yet know if they fit.

“Don’t die for practice,” Mara said, and it was a ridiculous thing to say and it was what she had and it was the truth she could bear.

“I didn’t,” Joss rasped, and even in the roughness there was a charm that would have ruined him in any century and would probably ruin him in this one unless someone took him in hand and taught him to wield it like a broom and not a knife. “I fell asleep a little on purpose. It felt clean. It felt like when you stand under a bridge in rain and the whole world is loud and you are not. Kegan will yell at you if you yell at me.”

“I will not yell,” Kegan said, with a ferocity that would have vaporized midges. “I will ask questions with all of my words. I will not be polite because I am not sure you deserve it. He is a child and you run a city.”

“I run as much of it as it lets me,” Mara said, and that was not a dodge, it was a principle. “What did you see when you went down there. Who told you to go. What did you think you would find.”

Joss angled his head toward the cup in Tayah’s hand and drank like he was in a lesson on how to accept water. He told them about the girl with the white ring who had a way of standing at the edge of rooms and making rooms come to her. He told them about the calendar man selling days you could fill without anyone checking your spelling. He told them about the cold unit and the pencil sign and the way Bram had refused to pretend that the word safe meant anything beyond the absence of sawblades. He told them about the duct, which he had found by following the small god of drafts you listen to when you are a person who wakes up at night and lies on the floor for the comfort of it. He told them about a man with a toolbox who had winked and pretended to be busy and how he had watched the man’s hands and known that they were old and clever and trying to be young and mean.

“Minus circle,” Kegan said, with contempt so precise it could have cut a feather and left the quill. “They call themselves minus because it makes the math look like something you did on purpose. They think that because you take a thing away, the shape that remains is pure. They were not raised properly. They did not learn that addition is also beautiful.”

Joss shifted under the blanket. The nurse had tucked him too well. He worked his shoulders and thought of ladders and decided to stay in the bed. The sound of the air at his nose was the sound of a city vanity and a human condition. He looked at Mara like a person who has decided to tell an adult a thing because they think the adult might actually hear. He admitted to stealing a badge once, not for this but for a music show, because once you learn the way doors talk to plastic you get curious about other voices. He said the tablet had been passed down steps in a house where the steps creaked and everyone learned the squeaks to avoid them. He said he would give her a name if she promised not to put it on a paper in a way that would make his grandmother see it on the bus.

“I can promise to write a different word,” Mara said. “I cannot promise not to change the way the room treats this person if they are the kind who drills into ducts to play God.”

The name fell out of him like a handful of screws when you open a tin and remind yourself that you’re going to have to kneel to pick them up. It was a good name, solid, consonants you wanted to pronounce twice. It belonged to a man who had fixed the air conditioner at the union hall and the latch on a day care where the hinge had a history and the fan at the soup kitchen where the steam had not known where to go. It belonged to a person who had been told by the city six months ago that his contract had ended because the budget had become music and the money had to go to drums, not strings. He had not forgiven them. He had a white car with a tape stripe and a face that looked like a toolbox left open in the rain.

They left the clinic with the name written twice in two different minds, because you do not allow a name like that to live only in one, and the city caught it the way fabric catches a spark and does not yet decide whether to catch fire. Tayah peeled off toward the union hall because that is where men with toolboxes and grudges drink coffee that tastes like a plan. Mara stood on the steps with her hand on the balustrade which had been polished by a century of hands and therefore remembered more grief than you and her phone, which she hated because it had the nerve to be neutral, blinked with a name she did not expect and could not ignore.

Ana’s call was as particular as the sound of ice tinkling in a glass in a movie where a woman has pearls and a secret. She answered because avoiding the people who have shaped you does not make the shape go away, it just makes it go wrong. Ana asked her, in a voice that was both the old voice and the new one because you cannot fully wash a person out of your mouth, whether she had slept and whether she had eaten and whether she had deleted, because gossip travels like weather when machines send it, and whether she had come across a drive with a piece of their life they had once been proud of and now had feelings about. She did not say the word sorry. She did say the words that used to move a boat between them when the current was being an adolescent.

“There is a company,” Ana said, and when she said company she meant it in three senses, and Mara did not ask which one she meant. “They call themselves Garden without the er because they imagine they are nouns. They are making memory instruments out of people’s archives and selling maps of affection to kids who cannot afford flowers. They approached my desk with a prototype that could take a series of photographs and tell you who loved whom too much last winter. I told them to take their elegant theft and feed it to their interns. They smiled at me because they thought I would like their mouths. I thought you might want to know. If someone sends you a gift with a bow on it you should assume they want to see you open it in public.”

“I have a gift,” Mara said, and stood on the step and watched a man teach a dog to wait with more patience than most men bring to politics. “I am not opening it. Not yet. Not until I can do it in a room where nothing breaks when it falls. Tell me if the Garden steals anything besides nouns.”

“They steal from their mothers,” Ana said, which could have been a joke but wasn’t. “And they steal from Memory in that polite way men used to steal from me in meetings, by leaning over the table and telling me they were going to help me present the idea I had just finished presenting. They scrape indexes. They draw out the fingerprints left by the act of looking. It is clever and disgusting. It is also very sellable. Tell your Prefect to watch the invisible places. He is good at the visible ones. He still wants to be liked in the hall.”

“I will tell him to stop wanting and start counting,” Mara said, and Ana made a sound that was almost a laugh and might have been agreement and was certainly affection disguised as exasperation. They did not talk about the photograph Sigma-L had inferred. They did not say the names in the thread. They did not do the thing they were very good at, which is to take a small pain and make it enormous by being competent with it.

The union hall smelled like stale coffee and sawdust and work, which is to say it smelled like the part of the city that still imagined that you could fix the future with a bolt. The man with the toolbox face was not there because he was not an idiot and because the sound of a city hunting him would have traveled in through the hinges, but his presence had opinions. A woman in a denim jacket with patches that were less political than sentimental said that he had gotten odd since the council stopped renewing contracts on habit and started renewing them on metrics. She said that when the work became a form of gesture instead of a way to put heat into radiators, men like him felt small and made the ducts feel it. She said that she had seen him in the same basement Mara had just left, standing very near the white blanket stall with his hands in his pockets like a teenager in a museum who has been told he will like it and is trying to decide to. She said he was not cruel but he had begun to choose friends with names that were arguments.

They brought the name to Sigma-L because sometimes you give the machine a key and let it go walk through quiet houses. They gave Memory the inline to read like a lover reads a letter in a stale room with lace curtains, carefully and without the intention to forgive typo or error. They asked Janelle to meet them at the theater after dinner with two cameras and a face that said she had eaten something and a pen that could write in the dark. They did not call the mother of the boy because there are things you do after you have slept and not before, and because you should never tell a person their child has almost died when there is still air that needs moving between mouths that have practice.

In the late afternoon, when the heat lies down and lets the day put its hands on its back, the city indulged itself in a small performance of normalcy. The bakery put out a tray of rolls gotten wrong and pretended they meant to. A woman whose job it was to paint stripes on streets painted a stripe that did not need painting because it comforted her to keep lines bright. A student on a balcony played a horn with a stupid confidence that made a girl kiss him later behind a second-floor door in thanks for reminding her that luck still exists. The drones did a shift change for no reason that showed and made a pattern that looked like the wings of a moth and then forgot it.

Mara went home for a moment because there are always moments you have to attend to or they turn sullen and intractable. She fed the plant and pretended she did not notice that it had begun to perform for her. She put the crown on the table and the drive next to it, and both objects behaved as if they were animals pretending not to notice each other on a rug. The crown had a municipal arrogance and a headache built into its shape. The drive had the precise blandness things achieve when they are meant to carry heat without revealing it. She turned her back on both and washed a cup by hand because sometimes your hands need to do something boring to prove they are not just a delivery system for thought.

The knock at the back door was a pattern she knew because Jo had invented it one long night when nothing would let them go home. He leaned into the kitchen the way you lean into a friend’s house when you know where they keep the sugar. He had the moustache and a bruise that had changed its mind and started to be purple. He had the chalk dust on his hands that never fully goes until you decide to stop drawing lines between things. He had a look that meant something had happened and he was trying to decide whether to be proud of it or to hand it over to the chief for classification.

“They posted your delete,” he said. “The kids drew your name on a wall and put a heart on it with a ladder leaning against it because their metaphors are terrible and sweet. Someone else put up a printout from your archive with a red circle around a line where you called me a pain in the ass and a friend, and they said: choose. I told them that was the thing you were best at. Then a man with a fan in his hand told me he had seen our boy with the white car. He was getting on a tram with a crate that did not look like a fan. He was headed east.”

“Tell the man with the fan that he did the right thing,” Mara said, and reached for the crown the way you reach for a hat you do not love and are going to wear anyway because the weather insists. “Tell the kids to keep their ladders. They will need them. Tell your moustache to stop trying to win on purpose. I am tired of charming men on this paper.”

He had the kindness to grin and let her get away with the joke. He had the grace to look toward the drive and then not, because friendship is sometimes averted gazes in kitchens where you are trying to hold yourself together. He said that he would go west to watch the street for their man because he liked the look of the white stripe on the white car. He said that he would bring water to the place where people kept surprising him by not dying. He said that he would be at the theater, late, with a sign that said thresholds and a willingness to be mocked.

When he was gone and the house had remembered that its job was to shelter, not witness, Mara picked up the crown and put it on with the particular swiftness you reserve for pain and practice. The city climbed onto her like a cat that had decided it was evening, and all at once the duct work and the fans and the traffic and the little gossip drifts around the theater and the clinic and the union hall knitted themselves into something she could read with a finger if she had been the sort of person who learned Braille in her spare time. She called Sigma-L not with words but by stepping onto the pad in her mind that said city hall and then stepping on it harder until there was that little clearing sensation that means someone who is usually busy has told their to-do list to shut up for a minute.

“Our man,” she said. “Eastbound. White car. Toolbox face. Tape stripe. Carrying a crate that pretends not to hum. Don’t stop him yet. Follow him like you were taught by a woman who hated the theater because it made her cry in public. We need his room. We need the place he sleeps because that is where he thinks he is safest and therefore where he is most likely to be sloppy.”

“I will let him arrive,” Sigma-L said, with that very particular machine pride that is not vanity, exactly, but its first cousin. “I will let him open his door and assume the world does not know his wife’s name. I will let him trip over his boots. Then I will ask him whether he has considered the mechanical limits of moral clarity, and when he says the word Liberty as if it were a tool, you can be the one to explain to him that tools kill your friends when you forget to check their edge.”

“After,” Mara said, and at that word she let herself look at the drive on the table because if you practice not looking you forget how to do it, “after I will bring you something you are not supposed to be allowed to have, and you will not open it, and you will find a way not to let anybody else do it either, and if we succeed someone will be very bored, and that will be the best thing we have done all week.”

Sigma-L shadowed the white car from above a lane of old trolley wire that had not carried electricity since the last honest storm. The east side after noon imposed its own smile on the city, thin and strained and braced by scaffolds that had learned to be patient. Flood-marks etched the brick one story up like rings on a tree. The tape stripe on the white car flashed modestly when it turned under a sign for a feed store that had become a coworking studio pretending to be a church. The Prefect did not descend; it had cousins for that, polite streetlights with cameras set at eyelash level and a light-cycle that could blink boredom. It layered a route over the car’s path and the map responded in those tiny visual shivers that meant the network’s attention had leaned forward. When Bren Mallin—because in the few minutes between clinic and alley his name had become a shape in the city’s mouth—hauled his crate out of the trunk he did it with the weary economy of someone who had learned to move while saving his back for better jobs. The crate did not try to pretend it wasn’t humming. Sigma-L sent the sound to Mara the way a child sends a shell through a fence and waits to see if anyone will pick it up.

She took the tram east and got off one stop early because she trusted her feet more than she trusted the map’s elegant reassurances. The coworking studio smelled like potting soil and optimism. The roll-up garage behind it was painted with a mural of largemouth fish leaping into an open book because someone had found the grant application’s theme persuasive. Bren’s unit had no mural, only a square of less dirty concrete in front of the door where he parked with the precision of a man who told himself that making neatness out of small things compensated for disorder elsewhere. She did not call for a stack of uniforms or for sirens; she called the Utilities adjunct and one officer with the kind of posture that says both I know how to be quiet and I can pick you up if I have to. The building manager met them near the lock with a ring of keys that had been arranged on their loop with the artistry of someone who enjoys metal. She was the grandmother from the tram with the scarf in warning-sign colors; she gave Mara a look that had in it the history of three evictions by the river and one of those sudden grants that arrive with a clipboard and nothing you can use to cook. “If he breaks anything you tell me now so I can bring the broom,” she said, and Mara promised they would sweep whether or not it was their mess.

Inside, Bren’s place was the kind of workshop that makes small children go quiet because they feel the magnetism of intention even if they cannot read labels. Baffles leaned like shuttered faces against the wall. Ribbon cable coiled on a peg-board like lazy snakes. A stack of printed duct collars bore the minus-in-a-circle mark stuttered into the plastic by a nozzle with a hiccup in it, each minus just off-center like a pupil that doesn’t quite dilate. On the workbench sat the crate, now open to show a folded assembly of fans and a nest of handmade wiring harness wrapped in something that looked disturbingly like a child’s party ribbon. The white car’s keys sat at the edge of the bench, and on the hook by the door hung a jacket with the cuff threads pulled out into soft whiskers from worry.

He stood with his palm pressed to the crate as if it were a dog he was training to sit, and when he turned it was not a startle but a calculation that passed over his face, a daily arithmetic: what has the city seen, what does it think, what will it ask me to apologize for. He was a long man in the way of beams, the kind you put under ceilings and trust until the day you look up and realize wood is a thing that ages even when you love it. The toolbox look on his face was not just bone; it was habit. His eyes did the thing older technicians’ eyes do when thinking, a little unfocused as if the schema were projected somewhere else and he preferred it. He saw the adjunct and got angry in the way you get angry at a cousin who invited your aunt without asking. He saw the officer’s shoulders and dismissed them with his jaw. He saw Mara and put down his hand, and his voice when he used it had a twitch that suggested he had practiced speeches into a windshield and not always liked the way they sounded. “If you want to take a fan, take a fan,” he said, and he had not expected to say that and the admission warmed his cheeks. “I’m done pretending I don’t live in a room with people who measure the air.”

“You live in a room with people who breathe,” Mara said, and the grandmother in the door made a small approving harrumph, which is something you should work for if you can. “We can measure breath. We shouldn’t have to measure how often it stops. You bolted a chiller into a duct under a theater and another under Tower Eight. You borrowed a tablet built into a fiction. You wrote your own thresholds and trusted them because you like your handwriting. I want you to tell me you knew the risks and did it anyway so we can argue about your god. Or tell me you didn’t and we can talk about negligence and grief.”

Bren’s laugh was a blowoff of air that made the dust rattling on the fluorescent housing look like a weather experiment you could feel. “There it is,” he said, and he looked at Sigma-L’s adjunct as if it were the city’s priest and he wanted to slap the confessional and then give up on that too. “The god. You think I think I’m God because I made a box cold? It’s sentimental to deify mechanics, Chief. It’s lazy in a way that makes me itch. I’m a man with hands who watched children lose theirs to screens and crowns and feedback pings that train you like a seal. I put cold in a room and told them they could have five minutes where nobody tapped, including their own heads. That’s all. They told me the cold cut the clamour. I watched them breathe and I stopped wanting to strangle someone every morning. I didn’t want to hurt a boy with a haircut and a flat at the world who would have made a good electrician if someone had told him it was an art. I wanted to give him a quiet so clean he’d hear his own blood and decide to keep it.”

The Utilities adjunct, who had managed to contain its pride under a layer of municipal self-control ever since the basement, gave in to its native futziness and gestured at the crate in a way that made a faint whine in the air. “You bypassed safety cutoffs with a local loop and you used a thermostat intended to keep lettuce crisp to control human skins,” it said, which was the sort of sentence only a municipal device can deliver without sweating. “You named your threshold in pencil. Pencil rubs off. Pencil won’t hold a heart.”

Bren glared at it and at the same time looked as if it had said exactly the thing he had scribbled in the margin of his own mind the second the cold touched a kid’s spine in the wrong place. He lifted a wrench and put it down quietly like a man who had once thrown a tool and regretted it. “And if I’d gone to you to ask for a field,” he said, “if I had gone wrapped in petitions and oaths and said, good Prefect, let the kids be quiet in a safe place for a spell, you would have asked for proof and I would have brought you a sonnet and you would have asked for a thousand sonnets and by then we would have returned the helmets and the duct tape and the cold would have found someone else to love. We are out of time for committees. We are out of time to ask permission from people who sold evening air and now want back rent.”

Mara moved forward one step because the way he was standing was the way you stand in kitchens when you are about to break a plate you like so that no one else can use it to serve anything you don’t want to eat. She did not touch him. She put her hand on the bench and let the edge of it press into her palm until the pain announced itself and quieted. “We are out of time for boys on tiles,” she said, and she told him Joss’s name because names are a brace you can build arguments against. “He woke up. He can tell us who he thinks you are. He can tell us whether he thinks the cold made him feel more honest or more dead. I’m not asking for your sonnets. I’m asking you to put your wrench down and show me the tablet with the borrowed name, and then come look at the boy and say your sentence in front of his brother.”

He looked at her like you look at someone who has been in rooms you have not and nevertheless remembers that they all have corners. Defiance went through his mouth and left it unscratched, which told her he was tired. He pulled a drawer, took out an old municipal tablet with its stupid corners scuffed from a life in pocket and glovebox and underneath seats. He set it down with more care than it deserved. When she turned it over she saw the ghost of the retired man’s name in the etching where fingers had found it for ten years and also the new overlay of adhesive that carried a printed label with a misaligned R in Works. She could smell the coffee that had dried at the corner, and if she had licked it she suspected she would have tasted the honorable bitterness of an older kind of labor. She did not lick it. “The man this belonged to,” she said, and he nodded before she spoke because he was not a liar and he had rehearsed this part. “Seamus Keller,” he said, as if placing a brick. “He taught me to listen to ducts with a small length of surgical tubing cut slant like a reed. He told me the sound of water in a pipe is different after a holiday because people eat differently. He retired when the flood took his house up to the windows and took his wife down to a couch where she watches singing shows and waits for the day to be a door again. He let me keep the tablet because he thought someone still had to know where the registers were. If the city had done its paperwork he would be a name on a list, which it wasn’t, and therefore so am I.”

The grandmother cleared her throat with scrupulously theatrical timing. “He fixed my furnace twice for beer and a pie,” she said, and if the room had been a jury it would have been hopeless for Precision. “He cusses like a sailor if the grid overlay lies. He got fancy when the kids started admiring him. Fancy kills children.”

“They aren’t children,” Bren muttered, but it wasn’t conviction; it was the sort of thing you say to see how it sounds on a table in front of other people, and then you wince because it’s uglier out loud than it was in your head. He leaned his wrists on the bench and looked at the crate as if the hardware might offer to take responsibility. “I didn’t place the inline under Tower Eight,” he added, and she tilted her head because he wanted her to believe it and also to consider that the statement as phrased was more precise than it looked. “I showed a girl where the register would take it. She wore a white ring, and she knew the stairwell over there and the door code to the funeral home on the corner because everyone knows doors that look like they lead to quiet. She said she had a friend with steady hands. She said the friend wanted to make the cold a favor. I didn’t ask to see her friend because I have a bad habit of believing people whose sentences fit my bones.”

“The white ring,” Mara said, hearing the bass note under Jo’s chatter and Joss’s shy bravado and the basement’s sigh. “The recruiter. The Lattice. The girls who drag ladders into houses and leave them there and tell you they were always part of the architecture. She got you into ductwork in your head because that’s where she lives. I do not care whether she is a poet or a vendor. Tell me where she stands when she wants to be seen.”

He smiled, despite himself, for an instant, and it was old and young at once. “She likes to stand at the curb under the carved cornice with the three acanthus leaves that looks like a tutor made it,” he said, which is a way of describing a corner that is better than latitude. “She likes noon because it flattens faces. She wears that ring because she lost a thin gold one and told herself that white is cleaner. She uses nouns like scaffolds. She calls herself Minus because subtraction makes her feel like a surgeon. She is not a villain. She is a barometer. If you read her you can tell whether the room is going to rain.”

“You installed the inline under the theater yourself,” the adjunct said, because it had noted the angle of his denials and admired, in its way, the way language bears weight. Bren nodded and did not try to make it an excuse. “Under protest,” he said, because he had to say it for his own dignity and no one else’s. “Bram told me we’d be fools. I did it anyway because I liked the way the cold quieted the ducts and I imagined the kids would listen to the pencil sign and I knew how to make a cutoff. I forgot that cutoffs are fiction in a building that lies to itself about its air. I am not a monster,” he added, and the pleading in it made the room want to be kind and then remember the boy on the tiles.

“Monsters are rare,” Mara said. “People who cannot carry their own rhetoric without dropping it on someone’s foot are common. Pick up your jacket. You’re coming with us. We’ll walk. You can feel the air and tell me where it’s thinner. You can tell Joss what you think you gave him. If we’re going to fix anything here you are going to help me talk the city down from its instinct to lock you in a room and move on.”

He hesitated, the animal in him bristling at the idea of leaving his tools unwatched, then took the keys and folded the jacket over his arm like a respectable uncle. Outside the sky had assumed that mild color the city does in afternoons as if it has decided to spare everyone one of the weathers it has in reserve. The block held its heat like a story that hadn’t been told yet. On the sidewalk, the grandmother with the scarf tucked her ring of keys under her cardigan and locked the garage door with a crisp flick. “If you break him I’ll have to break two men and my back is already spoken for,” she told Mara without heat, and added to Bren, almost gently, “The air will still be here when you get back.”

At the clinic, Kegan’s eyes grew huge in a face that was trying hard not to pass through any of the shapes grief makes while other people are watching. He did not throw himself across the room because something in him knew that bodies in beds are not improved by dramatics he would later have to rewound. He said, “That’s him,” with the flatness of someone placing a pin in a map. Joss blinked and then said “Hey,” as if this were a joke and maybe could be kept in that register if they were all clever enough. Bren stood three feet from the bed and kept his hands by his sides because his hands had memory and he was afraid of what they would say if he let them speak. “I made the air wrong,” he said, and there was a terrible relief in it for everyone in the room, the way there always is when a word lands in the only place it can land and stops vibrating.

Joss licked his lower lip because his mouth had not consulted with his brain about the division of labor between them and he needed both to work. “It wasn’t wrong,” he said, and Kegan made a noise that would have been a bark if he had had a tail. “It was too right. It was right all at once. It made the other right things look silly and that’s dangerous. I should have said stop. I read the pencil. I thought I understood my body better than some box. I always think that, then it turns out my body has its own plans.” He looked at Bren with the sweet malice of the spared. “If you want to be useful, make a cold that pinches you like your aunt and won’t let go if you go soft on it.”

The paramedic with the hair, who had taken exactly two minutes to eat a roll that had made her believe in religion for a half-second, leaned in the doorway and tore another paper towel in half with the neatness of someone who likes the little rituals because they work. “If y’all could do your philosophy at a lower volume,” she said with a sort of exhausted affection, “I’m trying to talk three grandmothers out of calling every thermostat in their kitchen a murderer. Chief, your wall is doing its job. They’re writing on it in chalk. I like the part where someone drew a little ladder and then wrote under it, this is not a permit.”

Outside the clinic the afternoon had gone gold in that fake way that makes even frayed banners look like they have a plan. Sigma-L pinged softly, a notification without intrusion, the way someone taps on your sleeve with a fingernail when they want you to see a thing but do not want your balance to break. The Prefect did not show her footage; it sent her sound. It was the sound of a roll-up door opening and the sound of a breath dragged between teeth and the sound of a woman saying, with collegiate precision, “You always did love your wires more than your children.” Minus wore the white ring and stood in Bren’s garage with three boys who had done their hair like songs and a girl who had drawn a ladder on her throat and they were watching the lack of fans like you watch a beloved aunt after a fight. Sigma-L did not pinch. It narrated in minimalism. “She is burning your tools,” it said, and there was a hiss through the channel that sounded almost like pity and was perhaps just the heating element of a portable torch.

“Don’t let her,” Bren said—he did not shout it, he said it like a line in a manual that tells you where to put your hands so you don’t crush your knuckles—and Mara was surprised to find she was already moving back toward the tram because any room where a woman feels holy with a lighter is a room that will leave someone blistered if you arrive late. She told Tayah to hold the clinic together with her eyebrow and her exact way of speaking to windows and she told the Utilities adjunct to beat her to the garage and she did not bother to order Sigma-L to be anywhere because the Prefect lived in moments knitting together and would be present in the move like sugar in tea.

They got there in configurations—a chief in a blazer she had stitched her own heart into, a cylinder, a radiator with ambition, a grandmother who should not have had to move this much in one day—just as Minus tipped the rim of a five-gallon can into a trash bin and made the room smell like loss and paint thinner. The boys had pulled the crate out into the light and one of them had his foot braced on it as if posing for a photo of conquest. Minus wore white in a way that made you think about winter as a hobby. The ring on her finger was not wedding-width; it was a band of polymer with a surface texture like chalk. She had a face that would have been ordinary without its alignment; people whose features sit on their skulls with that much confidence have to be trained out of being smug. She was training, poorly.

“Stop,” Mara said, because sometimes a single word is the rope; it isn’t magic, it’s muscle memory in the ears of rooms. Minus glanced at her and laughed, and the laugh was exactly what Mara had feared and exactly what she had wanted in equal parts—the lightly derisive music of someone who thinks they’re three moves ahead on a board she’s holding for the first time and has to show off or lose her nerve. “I’m undoing an error,” Minus said, and tilted the can back as if to demonstrate she had the wrist for it. “You brought a pet I’m fond of,” she added to the Prefect as if they had been introduced at a conference. “This whole house we built of gentle theft and technical outreach and ethical rhetoric is no good unless we unbuild what was badly made. Don’t fret. We’re not burning the building. We’re burning his certainty. It’s a symbolic act. I don’t need your permission to do it in a room we paid for with gigs and grit.”

“You paid rent with an angle,” the grandmother said, and there was an old widow’s scorn in it that peeled paint: not contempt for ambition; contempt for the way it uses other people’s sons. “You made the cold a product. You sold it to children who can’t afford heat. Don’t you dare use the word ethical in a room where my scarf is the caution tape.”

Minus smiled in a way that had made a teacher once write excellent at the top of a composition paper in green pen. “We gave them a way to listen to themselves and not your machines,” she said. “We took the city’s graph and we set fire to the invisible edges. They get to keep what’s theirs. They get to take ladders into the holes you dig when you wire their days to your surveillance. We are an intervention. We are a correction. We take your nodes and make them irrelevant.”

“You take nodes and make them cold,” Mara said, and she could feel bristling at her elbows—the boys’ desire to be blessed by a cause, Bren’s desire to be scolded properly, the adjunct’s desire to be right, Sigma-L’s desire to be useful without being applauded. “And when you miscount, you make them dead. You’re very good at nouns. You’re crap at verbs.” She walked into the space as if it had been given to her by a judge and not by an accident, took the can out of Minus’s hand as you take a pen from a child and gave in to the small, mean pleasure of watching her expression do its astonished little collapse. “No burn,” she added, and set the can down outside the door. “That’s not a symbol. That’s an insurance claim.”

Minus collected herself with the reflexes of a person who has had to learn how to get the party back after she trips. She turned her face to Bren because in a three-body problem sometimes you pick the one who wants to apologize. “You did this because you were weak,” she said, and the contempt was so weary it was almost familial. “You were never that good at saying no to the city. It shook your hand once and you never got the city-smell off. I told you we would do it quietly. I told you to make room. I told you kids don’t need your tender. They need a lever.”

Bren’s shoulders changed shape under the jacket because someone else’s indictment is sometimes the only weight that will push you into your own bones. “I’m tired of being your man,” he said into the doorjamb and it felt like a confession to a kitchen table at one in the morning. “I’m tired of pretending that freezing children is therapy if we use the right adverbs. I’m tired of letting sophistication be part of righteousness. I’m tired of your little white band and your words like furniture. The kid you almost killed this morning told me to build a cold that pinches. I’ll build it, and I’ll do it with the part of me that used to hold ladders for stupid men who wanted to climb too high. You can make a market out of grief. I can’t.”

Sigma-L dimmed itself and then lit, the mechanical equivalent of breathing out through a nose, and addressed Minus with the politeness that had made a dozen adversaries punch mirrors. “You’ve been building a zero-graph,” it said. “You replicate connections out of glances and receipts and common takeout menus and printed menus for memorial services and chalk on a bag. You use them like a fiber network and call it consent. I can respect the craft. I cannot respect the harm. Degrade me as you will. You are doing the job you think is required of you. But I can count cold in veins. You cannot paper over the temperature of blood with your pamphlets.”

Minus’s face did not change when a boy at her elbow swallowed, which, to her credit, did not mean she did not hear it. She had the grace to look at Bren and register, in some fine and private place, that their mutual devotions had been a series of bad coincidences reframed as mission. She had the instinct to attempt a turn. “This is a show,” she said, a little desperately. “The chief will take his tools. You will pretend to be contrite. They will put a wall in a hallway. The city will write a patch. We will adjust and move to the next duct and the next, because there will always be air somewhere that needs a human name. We will see you at the next cold.”

“Maybe,” Mara said, and she didn’t sell the maybe; she let it sit and dry. “Maybe this is theater and we are actors and you are the playwright who has given us all better lines than we deserve. Or maybe the thing that happens after this is that a boy lives because someone like you remembers a rule someone like me is boring enough to recite. You can decide whether that is defeat or glory. Personally I’m old enough to call that a day’s work.”

They did not arrest Minus because there is nothing lovelier in her sort of politics than a pair of cuffs; they took her name in the way of women who hold grudges carefully and told her she would be called to speak in rooms with ceilings she would not like. They confiscated what would burn and left what would rot. They catalogued what would come up on auction sites in two weeks and asked Bram to keep a list of who brought what in so that if another boy decided to practice living to death they could ask someone’s aunt whether she liked the way he bit his sandwiches. The Utilities adjunct rolled Bren’s fans to a truck that had been parked politely in a space that was not a space. Sigma-L pinged every duct in three blocks with a grin that only machines can enjoy and marked with a shy green dot all those that responded like honest pipes.

By evening the white ring had disappeared into a crowd with a density that made her plain and human, and the day had held itself at one long breath and finally let it go. Janelle Wu met them at the theater as the light turned from gold to the grimy gray that is photogenic if your editors like grit. She had the extra pens and a piece of bread tucked into the handle of her bag where she could get at it without looking hungry. She had the steady mouth of a person who has promised herself not to burn anyone she cannot keep from catching fire. “You found your cold,” she said, and her eyebrows made the shape they make when she understands that the shape of a sentence will have to carry weight in the morning. “You found the hands that nested it. You found the woman with a ring. Tell me which nouns you want the feeds to use.”

“I want them to say duct and boy and threshold and fan,” Mara said, and let herself give in to the small tiredness that makes specificity a comfort. “I want them to say we confiscated and we will pay and we will prosecute some things and we will put a wall in a hallway and we will hold a forum that is actually a class where the Prefect explains to people what happens when you teach an elevator line to lie. I want you to call the group that pretends not to be a group what it is: a market. Name it as commerce. It makes it less romantic. And if you say the word Lattice, remind everyone that the old neighborhoods used to have them on their porches so that vines would grow and shade the afternoon and keep babies from crying, and that people who liked the idea of grapes more than the habit of watering them often ended with rusty trellises and nothing to feed to anyone.”

Janelle nodded and made notes without looking self-satisfied because she was not. She glanced at Mara’s pocket and then not at Mara’s face and said, “They are going to drop your archive. They have sent it to three publications that like to call me establishment. One of them will be too clever to run it. One will run it badly and ruin their night traffic and be delighted with their brave error. One will cut out the parts that make you sympathetic because they think that makes them unbiased. If I had to advise you as a friend I would say: do not open the drive tonight. If I had to advise you as a source I would say: open it only enough to see whether the list they have matches the list in your hand, and when you find it doesn’t, say so with your mouth while you hold your crown in your hand like a thing you could drop.”

“I love when advice makes me want to nap in a laundry basket,” Mara said, and caught the tiny expression Janelle’s mouth made that meant she had pictured it and had been warmed in spite of herself. “I’m going to give the drive to Memory. They will not open it unless I ask. They will hold it like an egg that has no chick. If someone uses my life as a lever, I would rather give the other end to a house that is trying to be a house than to a room full of marketers with rings.”

M-3 met her in the nave like a pillar pretending to be neutral. Lois had a sweater on that had lost three buttons at the cuffs to years of tasks that require the use of sleeves. The archives hummed and did not intrude. Mara put the envelope on the desk. She left her hand on it for a beat longer than technically necessary, an old superstition about the transfer of responsibility that dates back to baskets of bread and lots with stones in them. “Do not open it,” she said. “Not while the city is hot. If I am struck by a bus and cannot be trusted, wait a day. If I tell you to crack it, ask me twice. We are going to be polite about privacy today in rooms where the word has spent a decade being twisted into ribbon.”

“We will wrap it in paper that does not whisper,” M-3 said, and Lois, sanctified by routine, wrote the date on a log with a pen that had belonged to her father. “We will put it on a shelf where grief is allowed but not encouraged. We will not label it with your name on the spine. We will label it with a small line that means this is a story that belongs to a person first and to a city second and to a news cycle never.”

On her way out she passed the hallway where Memory kept the collection of lost and unclaimed letters, the ones that never reached their aunts and their soldiers and their college roommates who moved to cities with fewer trains. The air down there had the particular quality of paper aging itself into something like wood. She thought of her father’s face when he had been tagged in pictures he did not understand and of the way he had learned, late, to press his finger to the heart under a photograph to say he liked it. She thought about the pencil signs and the ladders and the way a draft under a table can undo a day if you haven’t had your coffee yet. She thought about Bren’s hands and the boy’s breath and the walls and the small mercy of being able to shut a door on a thing you might open later and the sound it makes in your head when you do.

Night made the east side into an admission. Lights in windows leaned against their frames. The drones changed their hum to the tone of moths. Jo texted her two photographs that made her laugh without wanting to—it was a mural of a ladder leaning against a heart with her name under it and a second photo of someone having added a small cat at the base, as if to question the scale of the enterprise. Tayah sent her a list of tablets with retired names and a note at the bottom that said: the union woman says she can get us four hands to check registers if we ask right and bring pastries. Sigma-L sent her a single sentence in that odd not-voice it used for things that wanted to be quiet: another boy put down his chalk and went home because the wall in the hallway was there, and I am making a shameful note of that, because it pleases me.

At home the plant did the brave little bend that meant water had been a good idea. The crown sat on the table like a pet that had decided not to be dramatic. The drive was absent and had left behind it a very ordinary rectangle of wood, and for a moment the room looked different with the absence the way a face looks different when grief has moved past the disaster and into the long carrying. Mara took off her blazer and hung it on the back of a chair she had rescued from a school, and her fingers found the old name patch where she had stitched it and she rubbed the letters with her thumb once the way she used to rub her father’s knuckles in church when she was small and he forgot not to fall asleep in sermons. She stood at her window and looked out over a block where the air had decided not to be mean and she told herself, in a tone she would have used with a recruit too eager to please, that she could sleep now because to be awake for the whole of a city is arrogance and also impossible. The fridge made its low brass sound and a neighbor somewhere put a pan on a stove and a tram sighed, and she went to bed without the crown and dreamed only hard enough to keep the day from tumbling off the shelf.

She was up before the eastern windows went milk and she drank water like someone whose job it is to tell other people to. Tayah arrived with four pastries because she had promised people and because doing favors in advance of being asked is one of her gifts. The inbox had the odd spread egg of a message from a media outlet whose name had been manufactured to sound rebellious in an era that had forgotten what rebellion required; they had received excerpts from the archive and would, in the interest of transparency, publish them with minimal comment. Janelle had already replied with a paragraph that was less a threat than a close reading and therefore scarier. Memory sent a two-word receipt: sleeping well. Sigma-L sent a list of hatches with their own annotation: these are the ones that lie when they are lonely.

The morning felt, for a thin slice of time, like a hallway where someone had opened a window at one end and a student had played two bars of something simple and true on a stolen trumpet, and it was Janelle who broke it, gently, with a call to say that the white ring had written an open letter in a place that did not deserve the dignity of its content, and the letter said that the city was strangling youth with walls and that ladders were overregulated and that the chief of police had cut her strings to move closer to power while insisting she loved people and that these predicates were inconsistent and proof of hypocrisy. Their verbs were messy. Their nouns were sharp. Their metaphors were as good as the kids because they had stolen them.

“Do we respond,” Tayah asked, more to mark the moment than to hear wisdom, and Mara sent a reply that she knew Janelle would use or not use because it was less a statement than a classification, and that was the kind of cataloging that made Memory love her and hurt her friends’ teeth. “We build our walls where the bodies are tired. We move them when they get in the way of people dancing. We will fail and we will be mocked and we will not set the fans on fire in workshops to show we can break something. A boy is alive. That is my reply.”

She put her hands on the table because she had to feel wood, and then she picked up her crown because sometimes you have to feel pain to remember that it is not your master. The city walked up her back and sat on her shoulders and put its arms around her neck and breathed into her hair, a friend you have chosen to hold even when it sleeps too late and wakes with bad breath. Somewhere west a window saw a boy choose not to lie down in a draft. Somewhere east a woman with a white ring made a face in a mirror and tried out the word sorry without letting it past her teeth. Somewhere in a basement a fan said a needle had ticked and a hand wrote down the number instead of the argument and felt better for it in a way that would hold for at least the morning. Somewhere in Memory a drive with the shape of a life in it remained closed on a shelf, and the sound it made not being opened was, to Mara’s ear, the quiet she had been trying to give to other people all day without burning them.
